headline: Census Bureau’s Plan to Cut Marriage and Divorce Questions Has Academics Up in Arms
leadPara: Already, a series of unrelated policy decisions has reduced the ability to track family change in America.

headline: Don’t Hack the Envelope, Please
leadPara: On the eve of the Academy Awards, the movie industry faces shrinking screens and studio databases that appear increasingly susceptible to thievery.
abstract: A O Scott and Manohla Dargis share their thoughts on Academy Award selection process.

headline: The Rise of Evgeny Lebedev
leadPara: The son of a Russian oligarch has forged a strong role in British media.
abstract: Russian-born billionaire Evgeny Lebedev has immersed himself into British media world by purchasing four British newspapers.

headline: John I. Goodlad, Progressive Educator, Dies at 94
leadPara: Many of the views put forth by Professor Goodlad, whose study of American public schools involved more than 27,000 students, remain central to educational improvement efforts.
abstract: John I Goodlad, an influential educator whose study of more than 27,000 students, teachers and administrators in late 1970s and early 1980s documented problems plaguing American public schools, dies at age 94.

headline: There’s Hope for Nebraska’s Liberals
leadPara: Nebraskans and others respond to an Op-Ed article by Mary Pipher.

headline: Is the Modern American Dream Attainable?
abstract: According to recent studies, more than half of Americans believe that the prospect of a good job and a home with a "white picket fence" is gone, never existed or unachievable.

headline: Mario Cuomo, Ex-New York Governor and Liberal Beacon, Dies at 82
leadPara: Mr. Cuomo, a spellbinding orator and colorful personality who flirted with running for the presidency, lived to see his son Andrew follow in his footsteps as governor.
abstract: Mario M Cuomo, former three-term New York governor, dies at age 82; Cuomo led state from 1983 through 1994 and while he struggled with State Legislature to enact agenda for activist government, he personified liberal wing of Democratic Party, whose leaders twice pressed him to no avail to run for president.

headline: Ferret Fanciers, Ruffled by Ban, Are Eager for New York City to Lift It
leadPara: Disparaged as “little weasels” by Rudolph W. Giuliani in 1999, the furry pets are supported by Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration. The Board of Health will consider a proposal to legalize them this month.
abstract: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio's administration has proposed removing ferrets from list of banned pets in city, raising hopes of clandestine ferret owners; owning pet ferrets is legal in many areas of country, including New York State.

headline: Departing Lawmakers Bemoan the Decline of Compromise
leadPara: As the 114th Congress prepares to convene on Tuesday, some senior members who will not be returning offered advice to Capitol Hill newcomers: Partisanship is easy, governing is hard.
abstract: Congressional Memo; departing members of Congress say lack of compromise is responsible for decline of productivity on Capitol Hill, and urge lawmakers to do what is right despite political risks; all agree that Congress cannot function unless members of both parties are willing to find some common ground.

headline: The Paradox of the Free-Market Liberal
leadPara: Why personality and politics don’t always align.
abstract: Gray Matter column by Profs Ariel Malka and Michael Inzlicht describes their research into how personality characteristics affect a person's political views, which appears in Journal of Personality and Social Psychology.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology

headline: One Last Confluence for Mario and Andrew Cuomo, Proud Rivals
leadPara: On the day of Andrew Cuomo’s inauguration for his second term as governor of New York, his father, Mario Cuomo, died, commanding the state’s attention.
abstract: Andrew M Cuomo is sworn in for his second term as governor of New York on same day his father Mario Cuomo, three-term governor of New York, dies; Andrew Cuomo reflects on his father’s legacy during his inaugural address, and notes he read his father a draft of his speech at his bedside.

headline: The Pains of War, Long After Battle
leadPara: John Huston made his 1946 documentary, “Let There Be Light,” about soldiers with “neuropsychiatric disorders” — what we now call post-traumatic stress disorder — for the Army.

headline: Former Governor Spoke Willingly of His Religion and Politics
leadPara: Like few other elected officials, Mario Cuomo sought publicly to reconcile his religious beliefs with his political ideals, while challenging public figures who claimed a moral monopoly.
abstract: Former New York Gov Mario M Cuomo, unlike many politicians, was more willing to speak publicly of his religious beliefs, despite saying that talking about one's religion could alienate voters; Cuomo also baited other religious leaders who claimed they were morally superior.

headline: How Can Democrats Take Back the States?
abstract: Not since the Jazz Age have Democrats been in such a poor position in the states. Some worry that it might hurt the party nationally as well.

headline: Boehner Challenger's Website Goes Up, Then Comes Down
abstract: Representative Louie Gohmert, the Republican Tea Party favorite from Texas, said on Sunday that he is launching a challenge to take the House speakership from John A. Boehner, launched a campaign website to lay out his platform as a “true conservative” and said that it was time for the current leadership regime to move on.

headline: The Man or the Moment
leadPara: The architect of the Great Society wasn’t anything like the current president. But a new book suggests that their times, not their talents, tell the real story.
abstract: Frank Bruni Op-Ed column describes how Julian Zelizer book The Fierce Urgency of Now, which focuses on Pres Lyndon B Johnson's tenure, has caused him to reassess criticisms of Pres Barack Obama, particularly in way he has dealt with Congress; notes book shows how rare it is for presidents to impose their will on Congress, and that Johnson's reputation for manipulating Congress has been blown out of proportion.

headline: Hank Peters, 90, Dies; Built Baseball Winners in Baltimore and Cleveland
leadPara: Mr. Peters won a World Series as general manager of the Baltimore Orioles and helped rejuvenate the Cleveland Indians.
abstract: Hank Peters, longtime baseball executive who won World Series as general manager of Baltimore Orioles, dies at age 90.

headline: End of Anti-Americanism?
leadPara: Latin America’s long and deep hatred of the United States may now fade with Obama’s historic opening to Cuba.

headline: It’s All Right With Sam
leadPara: To the political right, Supreme Court Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. is a rock star.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

headline: Grading Bill de Blasio’s First Year as New York City’s Mayor
leadPara: Reporters for The Times covering politics, crime, education and the environment weighed in on Mr. de Blasio’s first-year performance.
abstract: New York Times reporters weigh in on first-year performance of New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio.

headline: Outside the Spotlight, Bill de Blasio Wages a War on Inequality
leadPara: In his first year as New York City’s mayor, Mr. de Blasio has taken steps to close the economic gap between the rich and poor.
abstract: Ginia Bellafante Big City column says New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio has taken significant steps to close economic gap between rich and poor in his first year in office; notes that city negotiated nearly $140 million deal with state to help subsidize rents for homeless families and has financed construction of nearly 3,900 units of affordable housing and preservation of more than 7,500 others.

headline: Live Coverage: Golden Globes 2015
abstract: Interviews and photos from the red carpet, reports from backstage, telecast commentary and more.

headline: The Freewheeling Event That's Part Performance Art, Part Dance Party
abstract: This weekend, the beer-fueled experimental happening stages its 66th iteration, which will include an interpretation of Chekhov and a Whitney Houston mash-up.

headline: Maher Hathout, a Powerful Voice for American Muslims, Dies at 79
leadPara: Dr. Hathout, who helped found the Islamic Center of Southern California, called on American Muslims to embrace their dual identity, and preached interfaith comity and understanding in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks.
abstract: Dr Maher Hathout,an Egyptian-born cardiologist who became an influential American Muslim leader, dies at age 79.

headline: The Backlash Against African Women
leadPara: They are powerful in government, but harassed on the street.
abstract: Op-Ed article by Sisonke Msimang, columnist for The Daily Maverick, observes that remarkable progress made by women in Africa has been accompanied by forceful backlash from cross-section of society; warns that backlash has started to become organized, expressing itself in decency legislation and public bullying of women; notes that in her native South Africa, women's movements have been successful in beating back attempts to undermine women's progress.

headline: America, Falling Short
leadPara: Readers discuss whether America should adopt European-style policies for caring for the populace.

headline: Broncos Have a Void That’s Difficult to Fill
leadPara: Pat Bowlen has owned the Broncos since 1984, but his familiar presence has been missed this season as he battles Alzheimer’s disease.
abstract: Denver Broncos, two victories from second straight trip to Super Bowl, find it hard to fill void left by owner Pat Bowlen, who ceded control because of health decline caused by Alzheimer's disease; team is busy preparing for divisional playoff game against Indianapolis Colts.

headline: Jeff Golub, a Guitarist at Home in Several Genres, Dies at 59
leadPara: Mr. Golub worked with Rod Stewart and Billy Squier and had a genre-crossing solo career as well.
abstract: Jeff Golub, guitarist who worked with rock stars like Rod Stewart and Billy Squier and who had a successful genre-crossing solo career, dies at age 59.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHELSON, GERTRUDE G
leadPara: MICHELSON--Gertrude G. "G.G.", who rose from humble origins to become a trail-blazing executive and an influential presence at the highest levels of American business, academia, philanthropy, and public service, died peacefully at her Greenwich Village home on Saturday morning. Born in 1925 in Jamestown, NY, G.G. graduated from Penn State University and from Columbia Law School, where she was one of six women in the class of 1947. At Columbia Law, she met and married Horace Michelson, a classmate whose quiet brilliance perfectly complemented G.G.'s sparkling extroversion. He introduced her to another great love, the New York Yankees, for whom she developed what this newspaper would decades later describe as an "unswerving devotion." After law school, G.G. joined the Executive Training Squad at R.H. Macy & Co., the retailer, where she would continue to work, in a series of increasingly senior positions in labor relations, human resources, and external affairs, until her 1992 retirement (She remained a Senior Advisor and Director until the company's merger with Federated Department Stores, at which point she joined that company's board). With each appointment, to Vice President in 1963, then to Senior Vice President for Labor and Consumer Relations in 1970 and to Macy's New York Executive Committee and Board of Directors that same year, G.G. was almost invariably the first female to have risen so high. But she quickly won over those unaccustomed to dealing with women in managerial roles, establishing a reputation as a firm but fair-minded labor negotiator (she was responsible for collective bargaining with the Teamsters and fourteen union locals, representing a total of twenty thousand employees) and helped Macy's successfully navigate the workforce challenges associated with the legal and social upheavals of the 1960s and the consumer movement of the 1970s. In 1971, G.G. was named to the Board of Directors of the Quaker Oats Corporation and over the course of the next three decades she served as director of numerous important American corporations, including General Electric, Goodyear Tire & Rubber, the Stanley Works, Chubb Insurance, Irving Trust, and Harper & Row; and as President of the Board of Overseers of TIAA-CREF; a member of the Executive Board of the American Arbitration Association and a Governor of the American Stock Exchange. When these responsibilities took G.G. to board meetings and similar events, Horace, by then a high-powered partner at a New York law firm but an ever-stalwart booster of his spouse's career, played his assigned role, taking his place at luncheons and garden tours organized for the "wives" of the corporations' directors. G.G's commitments and leadership roles extended beyond corporate boardrooms. She served on the boards of Spellman College and of the RAND Corporation, whose Graduate University awarded her an honorary Ph.D. in 2002. In 1980, she was named to the Board of Trustees of Columbia University and was elected its Chair in 1989 the first woman to lead the overseers of an Ivy League institution. It was during her tenure on the board that the University decided to admit women to Columbia College, after 229 years as a male-only institution. She was named to the National Commission on the Public Service; served as Deputy Chair of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York; was a long-serving Director of the New York City Partnership and a Director of the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York; served on the Emergency Financial Control Board, the state entity established in the wake of the New York City fiscal crisis of the 1970s; and was appointed to numerous commissions by Mayors Koch, Dinkins, and Bloomberg. In these many roles, G.G. endeared herself to colleagues through her sharp intelligence, geniality, and commitment to hard work. She approached board appointments as work, not honors, and discharged her responsibilities diligently. Surrounded by other powerful leaders accustomed to having their own way, G.G., true to her background in progressive labor relations and consumer affairs, earned a reputation as a conciliator par excellence though not, as a colleague emphasized, one of the "peace at any price" stripe. An enduring aspect of G.G.'s professional legacy stems from her role, spanning decades, as a mentor and friend to newly-minted Macy's executives and to a much broader circle of younger people who sought her out for advice and support as they began to make their way in the business, philanthropic, and academic worlds. Seeing these people advance to positions of leadership was a source of particular pride for G.G., and they--and the hundreds of rank-and-file Macy's employees whom she had come to know and help in myriad ways repaid her generosity with warm friendship and steadfast loyalty. G.G. was a devoted mother and grandmother and a doting great-grandmother and a central, beloved figure in two unusually close-knit extended families, her own and her husband's. She is survived by her sister, Mildred Terr, of Las Vegas, New Mexico; her daughter, Barbara Michelson and son-in-law Jim Heffron; her three granddaughters Phoebe, Sarah, and Claude; and four great-grandchildren, as well as legion friends, admirers, and others whose lives she enriched. Her husband Horace and her daughter Martha predeceased her. Plans for a memorial service will be announced at a later date. Those who wish may make donations in GG.'s memory to Friends Seminary or the Columbia University School of Law.

headline: A Pope That Makes Democrats Squirm and Republicans Wriggle
leadPara: Pope Francis’ commitment to addressing poverty and income inequality is changing the conversation in Washington.

headline: The Resurgence of Pakistan’s Military
leadPara: The constitutional amendment allowing special military courts to try suspected terrorists is a setback for democracy.

headline: G.O.P. Governors Face Test in Shift on Ideological Agendas
leadPara: Republican governors taking their oaths this month have expressed more muted, less-ideological priorities, but are likely to be challenged by conservative lawmakers.
abstract: Republican governors taking oaths of office across country express fewer ideologically focused priorities than in years past, but new pragmatism is likely to face opposition from conservative lawmakers; in 24 states where Republicans now control legislature, governors will have to negotiate legislative proposals that would further restrict abortion, roll back new education standards, and challenge Affordable Care Act.

headline: A Yearlong Celebration of The Nation's 150th Anniversary
abstract: The Nation, the oldest weekly magazine in the United States, announces plans for its 150th anniversary.

headline: Amid Seeming Progress, a Vicious Backlash
leadPara: “Klansville U.S.A.,” a documentary about the third wave of Ku Klux Klan activity, which came in the 1960s in response to the civil-rights movement, debuts on PBS on Tuesday night.
abstract: Mike Hale reviews American Experience documentary Klansville USA premiering on PBS.

headline: With Win, Amazon Shakes Up Yet Another Industry
leadPara: A nemesis for publishers, Amazon collected a Golden Globe for “Transparent,” becoming the first digital streaming service to win one for best TV series.
abstract: Amazon becomes first digital streaming service to win best television series Golden Globe award with show Transparent; four major broadcast networks win none, highlighting changes in television landscape.

headline: Senate to Debate Keystone XL, Setting Stage for More Energy Battles
leadPara: A measure that would force approval of the oil pipeline appears certain to pass, in a preview of clashes to come between President Obama and the new Republican Congress.
abstract: Senate will consider bill forcing approval of Keystone XL pipeline, foreshadowing more battles ahead between Pres Obama and new Republican Congress; bill is expected to pass, with Obama then vetoing it.

headline: Terror in Paris: Saving Freedom Remains the Task
leadPara: Readers share their thoughts on the attack on Charlie Hebdo and on a kosher supermarket in Paris.

headline: Study Finds Local Taxes Hit Lower Wage Earners Harder
leadPara: An analysis by the Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy ranked states by tax burden and concluded that the poorest have the biggest burden in local taxes.
abstract: Report by Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy finds state and local tax systems in United States are almost universally unfair, with poorest residents paying highest percent of their income and wealthy paying lowest; analysis finds trend is growing worse, and may be contributing to widening income inequality.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy

headline: Why a Generation of Adoptees Is Returning to South Korea
leadPara: A movement is raising soul-searching questions about international adoption.
abstract: Adoptee Solidarity Korea, group formed by Koreans who were given up for adoption and ended up with families overseas, most in United States, has lobbied for legislation in South Korea that has reduced flow of Korean children out of country; group's success has led to similar movements in other nations, all of them questioning concept of international adoption.

headline: What Happened to Risk on the Red Carpet?
leadPara: Unspoken edicts continue to govern the dress at Hollywood events, calling forth nothing more daring than spangled variations on a conventional prom dress.
abstract: Some celebrities are starting to take fashion risks at Hollywood's red carpet events, upending traditional couture standards.

headline: A Literary Life in Portrait Detail
leadPara: Two new books, a collection and a biography, delve into the life and work of the publisher James Laughlin.
abstract: Dwight Garner reviews books The Collected Poems of James Laughlin, edited by Peter Glassgold and Literchoor Is My Beat: A Life of James Laughlin, Publisher of New Directions by Ian S MacNiven.

leadPara: The Peter Blume retrospective at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts showcases that painter’s devotion to allegorical art.
abstract: Ken Johnson reviews exhibition Peter Blume: Nature and Metamorphosis at Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia.

headline: Your Free Speech, and Mine
leadPara: An enlightened society should be able to take the punch of satire and ridicule, even coarse satire and savage ridicule.

headline: Try This at Home!
leadPara: Does life imitate art or does art reflect life?
abstract: Chuck Klosterman The Ethicist column answers question about writing, producing or directing violent films or television shows if there is nominal evidence that such works can incite violent behavior.

headline: Forty Acres and a Mule
abstract: The origins, and failure, of Gen. William T. Sherman’s plan to resettle freed slaves.

headline: An Opulent Bet on Housing
leadPara: Jeff Greene’s Beverly Hills estate, listed at $195 million, is believed to be the most expensive public listing in the country.
abstract: Robert Frank Inside Wealth column observes that real estate billionaire Jeff Greene is selling opulent estate in Beverly Hills, Calif, with list price of $195 million, believed to be most expensive public listing in the country.

headline: Ex-Speaker of New York Council Becomes an Adviser to Cuomo
leadPara: Christine C. Quinn made her first appearance in her new role at a news conference on Saturday.
abstract: Former New York City Council speaker and mayoral candidate Christine C Quinn has been appointed special adviser to New York Gov Andrew M Cuomo; will formally join his administration in spring 2015.

headline: A Multiethnic Movement Emerges in Guyana to Counter Politics-as-Usual
leadPara: A few years ago, a gathering of members of Guyana’s two main ethnic groups — descendants of African slaves and indentured laborers from India — would have been unusual, but a new third party has changed that dynamic.
abstract: Guyana's multiracial party Alliance for Change has gained traction by giving voice to new generation of Guyanese who say politics have held country back by favoring race over merit, undermining economic progress.

headline: Insurance via Internet Is Squeezing Agents
leadPara: Technology start-ups with websites that sell many types of insurance and promise savings with comparison shopping are putting pressure on insurance agents, who collect commissions.
abstract: Growing popularity of online insurance portals is threatening livelihood of traditional insurance agents, who collect 10 percent commission on policyholders' payments; services, which often present side-by-side comparison of policies, are still a nascent industry, but Silicon Valley insiders say they could soon upend the 40,000 insurance agencies throughout the United States.

headline: 1945: Joe McCarthy at a Love Fest
abstract: First Glimpse looks at the first mention of senator Joe McCarthy in The Times, long before McCarthyism was a thought.

headline: Complexities of Choosing an End Game for Dementia
leadPara: Some wonder if a directive to hasten death by withholding “ordinary means of nutrition and hydration” should apply to a person who can’t remember it.
abstract: Ethicists, lawyers and older adults are engaged in debate over whether patients who develop dementia should be allowed to end their own lives via withdrawal of food and drink as specified in advance directive; at center of debate is whether a patient can choose to end their life after they become incapable of remembering decisions made while mentally competent.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Living Wills and Health Care Proxies

headline: What a Rise in Obama’s Approval Rating Means for 2016
leadPara: If the rating reaches 50 percent next year, it should be a hopeful sign for the Democratic presidential nominee.
abstract: The Upshot; Pres Obama, after year of low approval ratings, is having modest rebound before the State of the Union address, with 46 percent approval in past month; his ratings in 2016 should be indicative of whether nation will elect another Democratic presidential candidate.

headline: Lawful Sales Methods

headline: Don’t Blame Nafta

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPLETON, JEAN DUBINSKY
leadPara: APPLETON--Jean Dubinsky. June 19, 1919 -January 3, 2015. A woman of valor, courage and principle. Starting life as one of Dr. Martin A. Couney's famous Coney Island incubator babies, she went on to lead a life of drama and high excitement, participating in some of the most important social and political issues and events of the 20th Century. She was the only child of pioneering labor leader and political firebrand David Dubinsky, President of The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, and his wife and partner Emma. Born at the close of World War I, she lived through the Depression and participated in the Second World War. She met and knew some of the most important figures of the time, beginning with every President since Franklin Delano Roosevelt and Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt. A graduate at age nineteen of New York University, she studied there with the legendary philosopher Sidney Hook. She was married to Captain Lester Narins by Mayor Fiorello LaGuardia, whom her parents knew and worked with intimately. She was a student of, witness to, and participant in history. In the immediate aftermath of World War II, she worked with her father and the free democratic labor movement in this country to support, sustain and rescue struggling democratic labor leaders and movements in war-ravaged Europe. As unofficial aide-de- camp for her father and mother, she knew and worked with the great and the good, including General George C. Marshall; Financier and statesman Bernard Baruch; Philosopher John Dewey, the great pioneer in education and pragmatist thought; His Holiness Pope Pius XII; Premier Leon Blum of France; President Giuseppe Saragat of Italy; Mrs. Roosevelt; Joe Lash, friend of and biographer of Mrs. Roosevelt and her life with FDR; ground breaking United States Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins; John L. Lewis, iconic and towering President of the United Mine Workers Union; Walter Reuther and his brothers, champions of the United Automobile Workers Union; A. Philip Randolph, historic leader of the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters; Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo; Pablo Casals; Marian Anderson; Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher; Luis Munoz Marin of Puerto Rico; Hubert H. Humphrey; Adlai Stevenson II; Arthur Koestler; Nelson Rockefeller; Golda Meir; Yitzhak Rabin, and the founding greats of the State of Israel; Art Historians Meyer Schapiro and Andre Chastel, through whom she had the privilege of seeing the Lascaux Caves before they were sealed; Sir Isaiah Berlin; Orson Welles and his Mercury Theatre Company; practically every Governor and Mayor of the State and City of New York since her birth and most of the liberal and progressive politicians throughout the United States. She had a long and happy second marriage to Shelley Appleton, Secretary Treasurer of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and Chairman Emeritus of The World ORT Union. During this time The Fashion Institute of Technology asked her to found, develop and lead their first Jewelry History Department and through that work she connected with the great jewelry historians and museum jewelry departments throughout Europe. She then went on to found the American Society of Jewelry Historians. She was President Emeritus of the ASJH at the time of her death. She loved life and had a wonderful, rich and unique one. She was always interested in the new, and principled and determined in her thought. She was a voracious reader in subjects ranging widely from history to espionage, memoir, critical thought and beyond. Her mind was remarkable to her final days, which she lived with dignity and strength. She is survived by her beloved daughter Ryna, her cherished granddaughter, Emma, and countless friends at home and around the world. The family will be receiving, which will be announced privately. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date and will be announced. 1/3

headline: Experts See Signs of Moderation Despite Houthis’ Harsh Slogans
leadPara: Experts and analysts say it would be premature to dismiss the Houthis as Yemen’s Hezbollah, despite their alliance with Iran.
abstract: Diplomats say despite harsh words for the United States from Houthi rebels, who have expanded their influence across Yemen, they appear to be more moderate.

headline: De Blasio, Obama and a Flawed Vision of Liberalism

abstract: Op-Ed article by author Noam Scheiber suggests that New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio is struggling in opinion polls because he has focused on so-called 'identity group' liberalism rather than themes of economic populism during his tenure; predicts that de Blasio will focus more on issues that enjoy broad support like addressing income inequality in the future.

headline: Generous Republican Benefits
leadPara: The G.O.P. should help all parents, not just its own.
abstract: Op-Ed article by author Jennifer Senior observes that Republicans in Congress are far more generous with giving out parental leave to their staffers than their stance on issue for workforce at large suggests; notes that Republicans say government should not require employers to offer paid parental leave, but also that decades of data show that employers do not offer paid leave unless pushed to by government.

headline: Running for Daylight (Obama, Not Brady)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENTON, MARILYN
leadPara: FENTON--Marilyn K., passed away on January 22, 2015, at the age of 88, surrounded by her family. A graduate of Wellesley College, Lynn was a pioneer in women's health issues and spent much of her life dedicated to Planned Parenthood. She was a woman of grace and elegance, deeply engaged in the world around her until the time of her death. Lynn made you feel like the most important person in the room. She was enlightened and progressive, fiercely independent and resilient. But what most defined her was her extraordinary commitment to the love of her life and her family. Married for 60 years, Lynn and the late Dr. Arnold Fenton left a beautiful legacy of children, grandchildren and great grandchildren. She was adored by her nine grandchildren for whom she was a model of strength, intelligence, beauty and resolve. With much love, her family raises a glass of vodka with a slice of orange, and an extra glass of ice. Donations may be made in her memory to Planned Parenthood of Nassau County, New York.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  HU, HUNGSHU
leadPara: HU--Hung-shu, international artist and professor emeritus, designer and painter, personal architect and philosopher, passed away January 22 in Iowa City, IA. Born in Shanghai, China in 1935, he became Head of Design of The School of Art and Art History at the University of Iowa in 1968, where he taught until he retired in 2003. Engaged as an artist every day of his life, Hu Hung-shu painted striking black and white oil abstract landscapes, garnering international attention and exhibits for his personal technique. His sculptural works span the globe, including "D Forever" (Iowa City, IA), "New Leaves" (Ogden, UT), "Diminished Seven in Space" (Port Orchard, WA), "Solar Kaleidoscope" (Cedar Falls, IA), "Falling Light" (Fort Lauderdale, FL), and "Tomorrow" (Taipei, Taiwan). His awards include Progressive Architecture's First International Conceptual Furniture Competition and the Tokyo International Lighting Competition. His book, "Basic Design: The Cultivation of Wisdom, Reason, and Sensibility, was published" in 2008. His passion for art and design invigorated the classroom. His words resonated with his students, many of whom are active artists and scholars. He is survived by his wife of 46 years, Judy; son, Ching-chu (Jim); daughters, Ching-an and Ching-yuan; two grandchildren; five siblings and many nieces and nephews. He was preceded in death by his father, scholar Hu Sung- ping, and mother, Hseuh Gei- jen. A memorial is planned for April 26 in Iowa City. His artwork may be viewed at: www.huhungshu.com

abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof Salamishah Tillet and policy expert Pamela Shifman calls attention to researching finding that those arrested for murder, mass shootings and other violent crimes often have a history of committing acts of domestic violence; calls for early intervention in order to stop both domestic violence and the crimes that can follow.

headline: Richard Linklater and Ellar Coltrane on 'Nerding Up'
abstract: The director and star of “Boyhood” agree that the main character was much less hip than the actor playing him.

headline: Text of Mayor de Blasio’s State of the City Address
leadPara: The New York mayor’s full speech, as prepared for delivery.

headline: It Is Time to End Subminimum Wages
leadPara: Extending the full state minimum wage to tipped workers in New York would help combat poverty.
abstract: Editorial laments that New York State Wage Board, convened by acting labor commissioner Mario Musolino, failed to end practice of subminimum wages for tipped workers in restaurants, antiquated holdover that is kept in place by restaurant lobby; urges Musolino to reject recommendation by board and abolish practice, and calls on Gov Andrew Cuomo to support extension of minimum wage to restaurant servers.

headline: Tax Breaks for the 'Merely Affluent'
abstract: How can federal tax policy differentiate between “rich” and the “middle class”? Should tax brackets be adjusted for regional cost of living?

headline: London Theater Journal: In the Shadow of the Nazis
abstract: Nazis have crept into London’s theaters during the past month, glowering with murderous hatred and occasionally singing a song or two.

headline: Amid Economic Woes and Public Discontent, Putin Critic Sees Opening
leadPara: In an interview, Aleksei A. Navalny said economic woes and public antagonism toward the nation’s role in Ukraine have made President Vladimir V. Putin vulnerable.
abstract: Russian opposition activist Aleksei A Nalvany, who has been confined to house arrest for year, is organizing March 1 demonstration in Moscow against Russia's occupation of Ukraine; Nalvany has expressed hope that public opposition to Pres Vladimir V Putin's policies there and economic problems at home has grown enough to send strong message.

headline: The Supreme Court at Stake
leadPara: If the Supreme Court overturns the Affordable Care Act, it will first have to suspend its own settled approach to interpreting statutes. From Feb. 5, 2015.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

headline: The Secret World of a Well-Paid ‘Donor Adviser’ in Politics
leadPara: “Donor advisers” like Mary Pat Bonner have immense power in the world of political fund-raising, and their commissions are provoking complaints from big-money contributors.
abstract: Fund-raising consultant Mary Pat Bonner is among highly paid specialists who raise money for politicians and receive cut of proceeds, increasingly necessary service in post-Citizens United world; some donors have objected to high fees and middleman status of paid fund-raisers, while others contend that paying consultants on commission creates problems and is unethical.

headline: Rapping a Revolution
leadPara: The composer-performer Lin-Manuel Miranda meets with cast members from his new musical, “Hamilton,” to discuss hip-hop hustle and the founding fathers.
abstract: Lin-Manuel Miranda, star and writer of musical Hamilton, now in previews at Public Theater, shares his thoughts on theater, hip-hop and America's founding fathers.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN BUREN, BARBARA
leadPara:
VAN BUREN--Barbara.

Born in Brooklyn, August 28, 1929, died in her Manhattan home on January 31, 2015. Educated in Catholic schools, she further received a BS degree from Queens College, and a MS in Social Work from Columbia University. A Social Worker for many years, she championed the rights of children, incarcerated women, and ex-offenders. Many social programs throughout New York City benefit today from Barbara's relentless efforts and skillful fundraising. She retired in 2011 at the age of 82 from West Side Federation for Senior Housing and Support Services (WSFSSH) after twenty-one years as the Director of Development. Barbara had a progressive spirit and was particularly talented at organization, preparation and inclusiveness, tempered by spontaneity and a zeal for having fun. Barbara's talents shone in her position as Director of Community Liaison in the Office of the New York City Council President (1977-1979). They also led to her successes in acquiring funding and grants for many service agencies: Project Green Hope (1980-1986) and the Fortune Society (1980-1986) as Development Director and Grants Administrator, both supportive services for ex-prisoners, male and female; the AIDS Services Delivery Consortium as Director (1987); and West Side Federation for Senior Housing and Support Services (WSFSSH), as Directory of Development (1980-2011). Up until her last illness, Barbara for many years co-chaired the Community Board Number Seven, Committee for Health and Human Services. Barbara was deeply religious, and viewed her faith as including social and community responsibility. Her staunch beliefs, and extraordinary talents in organizing social movements propelled her into leadership roles in progressive activities such as Call to Action. As a progressive she had a keen interest in feminist initiatives. Barbara loved New York City and all it offers. Barbara frequently traveled with friends. She was fun to be with and to go out with. She will be greatly missed. Barbara is survived by her brother Jerome, her sister-in-law Mary; niece Michele Van Buren Kiefer; nephews David Van Buren and Christopher Van Holmes; grand-nieces Jean Van Buren, Skye Terebey, Carlin Van Holmes, Madison Van Holmes and Aurora Kiefer; and grand-nephew Edward Kiefer. Calling hours at Reddens Funeral Home, 325 W. 14 St., Sunday February. 8, 3- 5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass at St. Gregory Church, 144 W. 90 St., at 10am on Monday, February 9. Donations, in memory of Barbara, may be sent to Call to Action, 421 Eighth Ave., PO Box 8291, New York, NY 10116.

leadPara: The film “Boy Meets Girl,” written and directed by Eric Schaeffer, places sex and gender identity at the center of almost every conversation.
abstract: Jeannette Catsoulis reviews Eric Schaeffer film Boy Meets Girl, starring Michelle Hendley.

headline: Power Lifting of a Residential Kind
leadPara: Jay Wright and his Wright Fit company are behind several high-end fitness centers in luxury residential projects.
abstract: Debriefing column; profile of Jay Wright, whose Wright Fit company has created fitness centers at several high-end New York City buildings in collaboration with luxury condo developers.

headline: The New School Divests Fossil Fuel Stock and Refocuses on Climate Change
leadPara: The historically progressive school plans to bolster its curriculum to include more attention in its courses to climate change and sustainability.
abstract: New School in New York City is reshaping its curriculum to focus more on climate change and sustainability; school has also said it will divest itself of all fossil fuel investments.

headline: They’re Always Borrowing His Stuff
leadPara: For a generation addicted to borrowing and sampling, the British composer Thomas Adès provides a way forward beyond Minimalism and the avant-garde.
abstract: British classical composer Thomas Ades has influenced generation of American musicians across all genres of music.

headline: Wanted: Better Jobs, Higher Pay
abstract: Will job growth continue to accelerate? Is optimism warranted?

headline: Can the Church Return to the Faithful?
leadPara: Out of my 25 new Catholic cousins, only one is still practicing.
abstract: Jennifer Finney Boylan Op-Ed article maintains Roman Catholic Church's narrow and discriminatory views are responsible for driving away many faithful; notes church has turned out many in need of acceptance, like gays, lesbians and transgender people, or in need of help, such as addicts; urges Pope Francis to reach out to such people during scheduled visit to New York and offers hope that church may eventually return its faithful.

headline: Obama the Theologian
leadPara: The president’s focus on past sins has diminishing returns in the present.
abstract: Ross Douthat Op-Ed column traces Pres Obama's focus on America's past sins to insight from theologian Reinhold Niebuhr, who noted that no society is innocent, most recent example of which was Obama saying that religious violence is not limited to Islam; considers limits of this approach, particularly with respect to foreign policy.

headline: District of Columbia Sees Loophole in Congress’s Move to Halt Marijuana Law
leadPara: After voters in the district approved legalization last fall, a federal provision seeking to block it may hang on the interpretation of a single word.
abstract: Congressional Republicans have tried to nullify vote legalizing growth and possession of small amounts of marijuana in Washington, DC, via provision in federal spending bill preventing use of tax dollars to enact provision; district officials, however, say they may have found loophole that allows provision to move forward.

headline: For Saudis and Pakistan, a Bird of Contention
leadPara: A Pakistani court has canceled all foreign permits to hunt the houbara bustard, a favorite pastime of Arab royals, in response to complaints from conservationists.
abstract: Legal battle in Pakistan over foreign hunting permits for houbara bustard, migratory bird that has long been hunted by Arab royalty, has focused attention on practice; order to cancel all foreign hunting permits has become minor political crisis in light of favorable reception by Pakistani officials of Saudi Prince Fahd bin Sultan bin Abdul Aziz when he arrived to hunt the bird; Saudi royalty began visiting Pakistan to engage in hunting houbara in 1970s.

headline: Dean Smith, Champion of College Basketball and of Racial Equality, Dies at 83
leadPara: Smith built the Tar Heels into a perennial national power in his 36 years at Chapel Hill and became one of the game’s most respected figures.
abstract: Dean Smith, who became one of most respected coaches in history of college basketball during his 36-year tenure at University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, dies at age 83; Smith will be remembered for building team into perennial powerhouse and for his battle against racial discrimination at a time when segregation was still prevalent in the South.

leadPara: A memoir by David Axelrod, Obama’s strategist and political adviser.

headline: Bumpy Start for Jeb Bush Tech Hire
abstract: Jeb Bush’s new technology guru had a rough first day on the job, finding himself in a social media storm over some old Twitter messages.

headline: In de Blasio’s Budget Plan, an Emphasis on Public Safety and Social Programs
leadPara: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s initial plan for the 2016 fiscal year relies on prosperity to support a budget that includes no tax increases and virtually no service cuts.
abstract: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio unveils $77.7 billion 2016 budget, up 3.6 percent from previous year, that contains new spending on public safety and social programs, such as bulletproof vests for police, funds to aid the homeless and increased emergency response time.

headline: The Parent Agenda, the Emerging Democratic Focus
leadPara: A reinvigorated liberal agenda has emerged in the months since the midterm elections, aimed at issues of interest to the middle class.
abstract: The Upshot; new Democratic agenda is emerging--geared around families, with policy priorities like paid family leave and universal preschool; glimpses of liberal agenda can be seen in speeches given by Pres Obama, as well as his 2015 budget; platform may provide Democrats with more coherent message they can run with in 2016.

headline: New F.B.I. Headquarters Enters the Bidding Phase
leadPara: Several companies offered to take on the project for the government, which is expected to choose a developer and one of its final three sites next year.
abstract: Major commercial real estate developers scramble to prepare bids to construct new 2.1-million-square-feet FBI headquarters in Washington, DC; financial requirements for project include minimum of $1 billion in liquid assets; winning bidder will gain right to tear down aging J Edgar Hoover Building and redevelop its prime real estate, though return will not come for at least a decade.

headline: De Blasio, Sipping Tea, Has to Take a Sick Day
leadPara: Mayor Bill de Blasio, who like many other city employees has been battling a bug, canceled public appearances.
abstract: New York City government is disrupted as Mayor Bill de Blasio takes sick day.

headline: Emerging Hillary Clinton Team Shows Signs of Disquiet
leadPara: A public struggle over funding has pitted Hillary Rodham Clinton’s loyalists against those who helped Barack Obama defeat her in 2008.
abstract: Simmering tensions between longtime supporters of Hillary Clinton and the strategists who helped Pres Obama beat her in 2008 have begun to boil as members from both factions vie for position and influence in Clinton's 2016 presidential bid; key issue is controlling access to wealthy donors who fund outside organizations that support Clinton's campaign.

headline: What Is the Purpose of Society?
leadPara: We can’t fix our problems if we don’t know the end goal.
abstract: Mark Bittman Op-Ed column warns that business, not government, has inordinate influence on setting goals for society, which makes addressing concerns with nation's food and agriculture systems difficult; calls on progressives and their allies to take more prominent role in determining societal priorities in order to push government to work for people instead of businesses.

abstract: Profile of Elizabeth Magie, who is credited with creating the game Monopoly, although her role in its creation was largely subsumed by apocryphal story that game was created by Charles Darrow.

headline: Democrats’ Convention Choice for 2016 Reflects a Philadelphia Resurgence
leadPara: A city long overshadowed by nearby New York and Washington has learned to take pride in the creativity born of its relative affordability.
abstract: Democratic Party picks Philadelphia as site of its 2016 national convention, move that may prove to be an economic boon to city with highest percentage of people living below poverty level than any other large American city; Philadelphia's story is one of contrasts--while millennials are flocking there and beefing up town's technology sector, crime rate is still high and school system remains troubled.

headline: New York Theater Ballet Moves Its Relevés Downtown
leadPara: Diana Byer’s company begins a new chapter with a studio at St. Mark’s Church, an updated repertory and a season at New York Live Arts in Chelsea.
abstract: New York Theater Ballet, headed by artistic director Diana Byer, is taking on new life after losing their old studio in 2014; company has since moved their space to St Mark's Church and is updating their repertory as they prepare for their first season at New York Live Arts.

headline: Veteran Communist Leader Is Shot in India
leadPara: Govind Pansare, 81, was shot along with his wife as they were out walking. He was in critical but stable condition, while she was less seriously hurt.
abstract: Veteran communist leader and outspoken political critic Govind Pansare remains in critical but stable condition following shooting attack in central India; Pansare's wife Uma is wounded less seriously in attack.

headline: In Town Where Pitcher’s 266 Wins Were Part of Fabric, One Big Loss
leadPara: After the Hall of Famer Bob Feller died in 2010, the business model for his museum in Van Meter, Iowa, began to fail. The building was sold to the city for a new city hall.
abstract: Bob Feller Museum in Van Meter, Iowa, one of country's last free-standing museums devoted to single baseball player, closes after failing to meet operating expenses since 2010 death of former Cleveland Indians pitcher; museum building will be used as city hall and memorabilia will be distributed to various locations.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHIRELSTEIN, MARVIN
leadPara:
CHIRELSTEIN--Marvin A.

Columbia Law School Professor Emeritus Marvin A. Chirelstein, a leading scholar of federal taxation, corporate law, and contracts whose textbooks are still used by students across the country, died on February 16. He was 86. Chirelstein first joined Columbia Law School in 1954 to work on the Federal Income Tax Project under Dean William C. Warren. He then joined the government as an attorney in the U.S. Department of the Treasury and later taught at Rutgers School of Law and Yale Law School. Chirelstein returned to Columbia Law School as a visiting professor in 1981 and became a full-time faculty member in 1984. Two years later, he was named the first Isidor and Seville Sulzbacher Professor of Law, an appointment announced by then-Columbia University President Michael I. Sovern. In addition to being a highly sought after academic expert on taxation, contracts, and corporate law, Chirelstein was a beloved professor who once taught a seminar on the legal side of one of his favorite sports: boxing. A music lover who played the violin, he was known for his dry sense of humor and quiet wit and was adored by students. Two of his textbooks, Concepts and Case Analysis in the Law of Contracts and Federal Income Taxation: A Law Students Guide to the Leading Cases and Concepts, have guided generations of future lawyers through the complexities of the law. A third, Cases and Materials on Corporate Finance, opened the way to interdisciplinary analysis of corporate law. Teaching was Chirelsteins passion, in addition to tax. Upon his appointment to the faculty in 1984, Chirelstein told the Columbia Law School News that he considered himself an educator at heart. As a professor at Yale Law School from 1965 to 1981, Chirelstein taught three future Columbia Law faculty colleagues: John C. Coffee Jr., Merritt B. Fox, and Ronald J. Gilson. He also taught future U.S. President Bill Clinton, who commented: "I had the privilege of having Professor Chirelstein for both Tax Law and Corporate Finance at Yale--he was memorably patient with me in the former, and seemed pleased when I redeemed myself in the latter. He had a great sense of humor, forgiving me for reading One Hundred Years of Solitude in class and laughing at my answer when asked how I could be such a bad tax student and do so well in corporate finance: I said it was a lot like politics--someone's trying to gain at someone else's expense, and there have to be rules to avoid fraud and violence. It was the beginning of a long, if long distance, friendship. Professor Chirelstein, as I neared graduation, told me about a teaching vacancy at the University of Arkansas Law School in Fayetteville, and recommended me for a job that enriched and changed my life. I'll always be grateful for his gifted teaching, endless curiosity, and generous spirit." For Prof. Fox, Chirelstein first kindled his interest in corporate finance. "Students looked forward to going to Chirelsteins class every day, Fox said. He was remarkably incisive and sophisticated in his treatment of the issues, while at the same time being incredibly funny. It is a source of real pleasure that my son, Peter Fox 09, was able to have the same experience, taking tax with Chirelstein here at Columbia Law School. A trusted adviser, Chirelstein was often asked to provide commentary on taxation policies or reform efforts. In a 1994 Letter to the Editor published in The New York Times, Chirelstein supported President Clintons progressive taxation. . . . the distribution of national income has grown increasingly unequal over the last dozen years, at least in part as a consequence of the tax legislation that President Reagan put over on a gullible public, Chirelstein wrote in the Times. We are constantly told that American voters are disaffected, that they suffer from a political malaise, that they no longer trust their political leaders, and so on. Surely one reason is a growing sense that economic progress has been for the few. Progressive taxation won't solve the problem. But it helps, both actually and as a symbol of our national ideals. On Tax Day in 1998, Chirelstein appeared on PBS NewsHour with Jim Lehrer to again defend the U.S. tax system despite its complexities, which he attributed to Congress trying to administer too many programs through the tax code. We collect a trillion, three hundred billion dollars a year through the administration of our tax laws, and thats done largely by voluntary compliance, he said. I think anyone would regard that as an immense achievement. Professor John Coffee, who first met Chirelstein as a student at Yale Law School said Chirelstein was a Man for All Seasons. His students immediately learned that he had a martini-dry wit, a razor-sharp mind, but a uniquely self-effacing teaching method under which he convinced students that he needed their help to solve a seemingly simple problem on the blackboard, Coffee recalled. During the 1970s, his influential work with Victor Brudney illuminated the field of corporate law, but also showed that he was committed to fairness and preferred background norms of equality and equal treatment. Chirelstein graduated from the University of California, Berkeley, in 1950. He earned his J.D. from the University of Chicago Law School in 1953 and served as editor-in-chief of the University of Chicago Law Review. He is survived by his wife, Ellen, and his son, Paul. Our hearts are filled with sorrow at the passing of this great man.

Surely one reason is a growing sense that economic progress has been for the few. Progressive taxation won't solve the problem. But it helps, both actually and as a symbol of our national ideals. On Tax Day in 1998, Chirelstein appeared on PBS NewsHour with Jim Lehrer to again defend the U.S. tax system despite its complexities, which he attributed to Congress trying to administer too many programs through the tax code. We collect a trillion, three hundred billion dollars a year through the administration of our tax laws, and thats done largely by voluntary compliance, he said. I think anyone would regard that as an immense achievement. Professor John Coffee, who first met Chirelstein as a student at Yale Law School said Chirelstein was a Man for All Seasons. His students immediately learned that he had a martini-dry wit, a razor-sharp mind, but a uniquely self-effacing teaching method under which he convinced students that he needed their help to solve a seemingly simple problem on the blackboard, Coffee recalled. During the 1970s, his influential work with Victor Brudney illuminated the field of corporate law, but also showed that he was committed to fairness and preferred background norms of equality and equal treatment. Chirelstein graduated from the University of California, Berkeley, in 1950. He earned his J.D. from the University of Chicago Law School in 1953 and served as editor-in-chief of the University of Chicago Law Review. He is survived by his wife, Ellen, and his son, Paul. Our hearts are filled with sorrow at the passing of this great man. 1/3

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARMER, THOMAS
leadPara: FARMER--Thomas L., died February 5, 2015 at his home in northwest Washington D.C. surrounded by his wife and three children. He was 91 years old. The cause was progressive supranuclear palsy. Born in Berlin in 1923, to an American father and a German-Jewish mother, Thomas Farmer graduated from Great Neck High School in 1940 and from Harvard College (A.B. 1943) where he was a member of the Editorial Board of the Harvard Crimson. He served in the U.S. Army from 1943 to 1946. At war's end, as a member of the Military Intelligence Division of the Combined Chiefs of Staff, Washington, he debriefed Wehrmacht officers on German Army Order of Battle. He thereupon read law at Brasenose College, Oxford (LL.B.1948) and graduated from Harvard Law School (LL.M. 1950). His marriage to Elizabeth Becker in 1951 ended in divorce in 1970. Thomas Farmer combined private law practice with public service. From 1951 to 1954 he was a Covert Operations Officer for the CIA. From 1954 to 1964, he was an associate of the New York law firm of Simpson, Thacher and Bartlett. He worked in John Kennedy's presidential campaign in 1959 and in 1960 and as the General Counsel for the State Department's U.S. Agency for International Development from 1964 to 1968. He served as Chairman of the Intelligence Oversight Board during the Carter administration. From 1970 to 1994 he was partner in the law firm Prather Seeger Doolittle and Farmer. Thomas Farmer was deeply involved in developing relations between the United States and Germany. He helped found the American Institute for Contemporary German Studies (1983) and the American Academy in Berlin (1994). He received the Commander's Cross of the Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany in 1997. He is survived by his wife of twelve years, Wanda Walton, his children: Daniel Farmer, Sarah Farmer and Elspeth Farmer, and five grandchildren.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTFRIED, ALEX
leadPara:
GOTTFRIED--Alex.

Alex Gottfried, professor of political science and progressive political activist, died March 18, 2014. He was 94 and lived in Seattle. Dr. Gottfried's central passion was civil liberties. On the Board of the ACLU's Washington affiliate from 1961 to 1988, he was a gadfly who pushed the organization to broaden its definition of civil liberties. Born October 23, 1919, in Hungary, he grew up in Chicago. He joined the U.S. Army Air Corps in 1942, where he headed a de-Nazification unit of the U.S. military government in occupied Germany. He married the former Betty Sue Davidson in 1943. After the war he earned a PhD from the University of Chicago. He joined the political science faculty of the University of Washington, Seattle, in 1950 and taught there until he retired in 1982. He wrote "Boss Cermak of Chicago: A Study of Political Leadership", a primary text on American"machine politics." Dr. Gottfried is survived by his wife of 70 years, Sue Davidson Gottfried; daughter, Erika Gottfried, granddaughter, Sophia Fischler-Gottfried, and son-in-law, Steven Fischler.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Emerges as an Unexpected Champion of Religion

headline: Stop Playing the ‘Race Card’ Card
leadPara: People who claim that certain accusations of racism are exaggerated seek to do what they condemn: shut down the debate with a scalding-hot charge.

headline: The Brain’s Empathy Gap

abstract: Jeneen Interlandi article notes success in art of collective persuasion--getting people to change their behaviors for good of society, but what has not come easy is persuading them to identify with those perceived as outsiders; MIT neuroscientist Emile Bruneau has been supplementing psychological experiments with brain scans, trying to track people's ability to empathize with others, and when it fails, in effort to learn how to build that ability back up.

abstract: Jana Partners sells a 20 percent stake to an investment firm. | Markets cheer the Fed’s statement on rates. | BlackRock has a new breed of E.T.F. | A top Wall Street lawyer blasts the regulatory environment.

abstract: Political Memo; Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu's re-election victory has resonated through American politics, including complicating situation for Hillary Clinton in her presidential run; she is presented with widening polarization among Jewish Democrats over Netanyahu and how United States should deal with his hawkish stance; Clinton runs risk of alienating these supporters if she criticizes Israel.

headline: Do the Democrats and Israel Have a Future Together?
leadPara: Benjamin Netanyahu’s problem in the United States isn’t liberal Jews; it’s everyone else.

leadPara: The story of Monopoly, and the woman unrecognized for her role in its creation.
abstract: James McManus reviews book The Monopolists: Obsession, Fury, and the Scandal Behind the World’s Favorite Board Game by Mary Pilon.

abstract: Some supporters of Hillary Rodham Clinton, a staunch supporter of Israel, say she need not worry about excessive blowback from moderate Jewish supporters even if she were to join progressive Jews in criticizing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

leadPara: The March 13 death of Manuela Pavesi, a photographer, stylist and Miuccia Prada’s close collaborator, saddened the fashion world.

headline: Philadelphia Commissioner Steps Into Fray Between Police and Public
leadPara: Even in a city with a black chief of police, relations between law enforcement and the public are strained.
abstract: Philadelphia Police Commissioner Charles H Ramsey emerges as unlikely leader in national police reform movement born out of fatal encounters of unarmed African-American men and boys with police nationwide; took rare step of asking Justice Dept to review practices of his department, and has placed himself in middle of controversy surrounding death of Brandon Tate-Brown, who was killed by police in December 2014.

headline: Chicago Mayor’s Race Is Cast as a Test of Liberalism
leadPara: Mayor Rahm Emanuel, a former chief of staff to President Obama, faces a surprisingly competitive runoff against Jesus G. Garcia, who is supported by progressives frustrated with business-backed politics.
abstract: Progressive groups both in Chicago and nationally are hoping to use competitive runoff election in Chicago between Mayor Rahm Emanuel and Jesus G Garcia to highlight Democratic Party establishment's ties to wealthy donors and business; fact that Emanuel has record of accomplishment on many liberal priorities illustrates expectations of a resurgent political left.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOHEN, FREDERICK
leadPara:
BOHEN--Frederick M.

After a distinguished career in university administration and public service, Frederick Martin Bohen died peacefully at home in Manhattan on March 15, succumbing to progressive lung failure at age 77. In both his personal and professional life, he was admired for his dedication, leadership, kindness and gentlemanly qualities. Before retiring in 2005, Bohen served as Executive VP and COO at Rockefeller University in New York City. His career in academic administration began at Princeton's Woodrow Wilson School in 1964. Public service took him to Washington, where he was on the White House domestic policy staff in the Johnson administration, and in the Carter administration at HEW and HHS. In the 1970s he twice ran as a Democratic candidate for Congress in New Jersey. Bohen resumed academic administration in the early 1980s, first at the University of Minnesota, then at Brown University, and finally at Rockefeller in 1990. Between stints in government and academia, he worked in public television and philanthropy at WNET and the Ford Foundation. He served on various corporate and charitable boards, including: Apache Oil Company; Sallie Mae; the Aaron Diamond AIDS Research Center; the American Council of Learned Societies; the Polish American Freedom Foundation; and the TEAK Fellowship. Bohen grew up in Ridgewood, NJ, son of Arthur and Lillian Bohen, and brother of Helen B. O'Bannon. He attended Harvard College on an NROTC scholarship, graduating in 1959. After his naval service, he received his Master's in Public Affairs from the Woodrow Wilson School in 1966. He is survived by his three daughters, Shawn Jacqueline Bohen, Kim Penelope Bohen and Courtney Lisa Bohen, and eight grandchildren. He was formerly married to Halcyone Harger Bohen of Washington, D.C. Gifts may be made in his memory to the TEAK Fellowship, which helps talented New York City students from low-income families gain admission to top high schools and colleges. He was a long-time Trustee at TEAK. teakfellowship.org.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHECHTER, DANNY
leadPara:
SCHECHTER--Danny,

died on March 19, in New York City. Danny Schechter, aka "The News Dissector" aka "troublemaker," grew up in the Bronx, in the progressive, union-sponsored Amalgamated Houses. His immigrant grandparents were garment workers who brought their socialist ideals with them from the Old Country. His mother Ruth Lisa Schechter was a secretary who became a poet. His father, Jerry Schechter was a pattern-maker who became a sculptor. Danny attended DeWitt Clinton High School, where he served as the editor-in-chief of the legendary Clinton News. From there it was on to Cornell, Syracuse, the London School of Economics, and Harvard as a Neiman Fellow. But this is only a small part of his life's journey. He joined the Northern Student Movement in high school and became actively involved in the Civil Rights Movement, going down to Mississippi in 1964. He became a leader in the movement to end the Vietnam War, was a member of SDS and began a lifelong commitment to South Africa in 1967 as an original member of the "London Recruits." He fought tirelessly against Apartheid from then on. Danny never hesitated to put his convictions on the line. In the 1970s, he turned back to his first love - journalism - and became the "news dissector" at radio station WBCN in Boston. He wove news and music together in collages that not only reported the day's events but also helped explain how the world worked. He was a huge influence on those who valued his independent perspective - and trusted him. He went on to become a prolific, Emmy award-winning TV producer and filmmaker, who made "South Africa Now," six films about Mandela, and spent decades criticizing and cajoling the media to do a better job covering the news. He interviewed Bob Dylan. He walked with Jesse Jackson. He embraced the Dali Lama. Malcolm X nicknamed him "Danny X." He was invited by Nelson Mandela to his inauguration. He was determined to "let justice roll down like waters" and to see all people free. His commitment and integrity were never for sale. Friend to thousands. Great and loving dad to Sarah, brother to Bill and Denzil, and uncle to Ethan and Jamie. He was so much fun. So much energy. A solar flare. A meteor across our sky. If there is an afterlife, you should soon be receiving a blog post from our beloved Danny Schechter, "the news dissector." In lieu of flowers, please send donations in Danny's name to Cornell University, Cornell University Office of Alumni Affairs, 130 E. Seneca Street, Ithaca, NY 14850. Please specify that the donation is for the "Civil Rights History & Memorial Project," which will honor Cornell students like Danny who went down south during the 1960's. We do not want this history to be lost, but to live on and inspire students today. A celebration of Danny's life will be held in New York City in the spring, at a date and place to be announced.

abstract: Political Memo; Democratic strategists share their thoughts on how challenger could wrest 2016 Democratic presidential nomination from Hillary Clinton, who is considered overwhelming favorite.

headline: The False Hope of a Limited Government, Built on Tax Breaks
leadPara: Protected from democratic accountability, the government developed into a Rube Goldberg contraption that has a weak claim to a defensible social purpose.

leadPara: Jesus G. Garcia’s strategy of building a multicultural coalition to unseat Mayor Rahm Emanuel has not been able to overcome ethnic rivalries.
abstract: Chicago mayoral candidate Jesus G Garcia is trying to assemble coalition of white liberals, blacks and Latinos, but faces prominent lead by Mayor Rahm Emanuel ahead of runoff election; challenge for Garcia is overcoming ethnic rivalries and suspicions.

headline: Election in Scarred Ferguson Carries Hope of ‘New Tomorrow’
leadPara: Activists in Ferguson, Mo., are looking to City Council elections on Tuesday to change the face of the mostly black city’s predominantly white political leadership.
abstract: Activists in Ferguson, Mo, are making effort to bring voters to polls in first City Council election held since police officer Darren Wilson shot black teenager Michael Brown; activists hope to bring change to city where only one of seven Council members is black and 67 percent of population is African-American.

headline: In Chicago’s Reshaped Politics, Unions Are Divided Over Mayoral Race
leadPara: Labor is vital to the chances of Jesus G. Garcia in Tuesday’s runoff. But Mayor Rahm Emanuel is receiving a surprisingly solid amount of union support.
abstract: Series of legal decisions and number of anti-corruption investigations have upended electoral landscape in Chicago by dismantling Democratic political machine that dominated elections for decades; change explains in part Mayor Rahm Emanuel's difficult re-election campaign, and accounts for large role organized labor has played in election, particularly in way Chicago Teachers Union has backed Emanuel's rival Jesus G Garcia.

headline: At Success Academy Charter Schools, High Scores and Polarizing Tactics
leadPara: Students at the charter schools, led by Eva S. Moskowitz, outperform their public school peers, but the schools’ methods and culture are not for everyone.
abstract: Visits to schools in Success Academy's charter network, along with interviews with current and former employees, reveal a system that is designed around achieving better results through strict demands, rules and expectations; charter school system, led by Eva S Moskowitz, is particularly polarizing in New York City, in part because of its skirmishes with teachers' union; system regularly outperforms public schools even in wealthier suburbs on standardized tests.

headline: Rev. Gardner C. Taylor, Powerful Voice for Civil Rights, Dies at 96
leadPara: Mr. Taylor, the former senior pastor of the Concord Baptist Church of Christ in Brooklyn, had an impact as a political force that reached far beyond his 10,000-member congregation.
abstract: Rev Gardner C Taylor, Baptist minister who became an influential voice for civil rights and one of the nation’s most eloquent churchmen, dies at age 96.

headline: To Accompany Belle Mare’s Wistful Pop, a Stunning Journey to Burkina Faso
abstract: The band’s new music video comprises footage shot by the documentarian and artist Nicole Mackinlay Hahn.

headline: Letters to the Editor
leadPara: Readers respond to articles in Science Times.

headline: Today in Politics: Some Hiccups Await Rand Paul’s Big Day
abstract: Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky enters the race for the White House on Tuesday in Louisville, Ky., where he will become the second Republican to formally declare.

headline: In Napa Valley, a Bike Ride With Food as Co-Star
abstract: The Bottega Gran Fondo in California’s Napa Valley offers a bike ride with breaks for food created by well-known chefs.

headline: McDonald’s Turns ‘Progressive’
leadPara: Instead of playing catch-up, it should really transform itself.
abstract: Mark Bittman Op-Ed column suggests that McDonald's efforts to play catch-up to competitors, such as raising wages in company-owned restaurants and phasing out use of chickens raised with antibiotics, have failed because they have only been half measures; urges company to transform itself into truly progressive company.

headline: House Hunting in ... England
leadPara: With prices in London surging over the last several years, a ripple effect has spread out to the so-called Home Counties, including Hertfordshire, on the city’s northern border.

headline: Silicon Valley Not So Friendly to Families: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: Claire Cain Miller writes about her reporting on Silicon Valley and the fact that an industry renowned for generous perks is not particularly family friendly.

headline: I.R.S. Shortcut to Tax-Exempt Status Is Under Fire
leadPara: The agency introduced the application last year to ease a backlog of cases, but critics say the process is now so easy that it invites fraud.
abstract: Number of tax lawyers, nonprofits and state enforcement agents have raised concerns about Internal Revenue Service's form 1023-EZ, simplified online application for tax-exempt status introduced in 2014; critics say form can lead organizations to make legal missteps and that it makes it easier for bad actors to commit fraud.

headline: Council Vote in Ferguson Brings Promise and Pause
leadPara: Three new members were elected to a body that still must navigate fallout from the police killing of an unarmed black teenager last summer.
abstract: Ella M Jones, Brian P Fletcher and Wesley Bell are elected to the Ferguson, Mo, City Council, body that still faces fallout from death of Michael Brown one year earlier; some detractors say background of Bell, who began his career as a public defender and has previous involvement with the municipal court system, makes him part of region's problematic political establishment.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, RUTH
leadPara: GOTTLIEB--Ruth, celebrated the arts every day sharing her passion with friends, family, and professional colleagues. Despite being diagnosed with progressive supranuclear palsy, she never lost her passion and continued sharing her amazing energy and panache. As Program Coordinator of the Contemporary Collectors Circle at Stanford University's Cantor Arts Center, Ruth spent nearly 20 years educating collectors by leading art tours of private and public collections worldwide. She passed away Tuesday at the age of 76. Ruth is predeceased by her loving husband of 46 years, Jerome. She is survived by her brother Irwin Weiss of Las Vegas; two sons Adam Gottlieb of Davis, CA and Geoffrey Gottlieb of Los Angeles; daughters-in-law Elizabeth Nelson and Rebecca Plack; and twin grandchildren, Jonah and Margo. A graveside service will take place Sunday, April 12 at 10:30am at Cemetery Beth David in Elmont, New York.
