headline: Remains From Lincoln’s Last Day
leadPara: Today’s Republican Congress wouldn’t pass a Homestead Act, which provided a path to citizenship and prosperity for those who were neither citizens nor prosperous.
abstract: Timothy Egan Op-Ed column considers expansive legacy of Pres Abraham Lincoln on 150th anniversary of his death; observes Republicans of 2015, unlike Lincoln's Republicans, have turned against philosophy that shaped their party; holds modern GOP would resist many of Lincoln's greatest acts and are united in opposition to progressive legislation.

headline: Jim Berk Steps Down as Participant Media’s Chief
leadPara: After eight years leading the company known for backing films with a progressive bent, Jim Berk is resigning as it moves into new areas.

headline: Brazil: 3 Ex-Lawmakers Arrested in Corruption Case
leadPara: The federal police arrested three former lawmakers who are suspected of involvement in a corruption scheme at the state-run oil giant Petrobras. They are the first politicians to be arrested in the scandal.
abstract: Three former Brazilian lawmakers are arrested in connection with ongoing bribery and corruption scandal involving state-run oil company Petrobras; first politicians to be arrested in scandal, the three are accused of being involved with black-market money dealers in scheme involving at least $800 million in bribes.

headline: Unequal, Yet Happy
leadPara: ​Consumerism explains why we’re not angrier about the growth in extreme wealth.
abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof Steven Quartz and political scientist Anette Asp explores why record inequality in American society has not resulted in expected uptick in unhappiness due to envy; suggests that culture of consumerism has made relationship between income and status more complex; warns that uncoupling of happiness and income equality has negative consequences for political and economic systems.

headline: The Moral Bucket List
leadPara: What kind of adventures produce goodness, rather than build résumés?
abstract: David Brooks Op-Ed column, adapted from book The Road to Character, describes his quest to find out how deeply good people ended up that way; offers listing of experiences one should have that will contribute to richest possible inner life.

headline: Sneak Peek at Hillary Clinton on Campaign
leadPara: As Hillary Rodham Clinton begins her campaign for the presidency this week, she's starting low-key, but soon she will prefer a focus on issues.

headline: No Hillary Clinton Endorsement Just Yet From Bill de Blasio
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York, who was managed Hillary Rodham Clinton’s 2000 United States Senate campaign, declined to endorse Mrs. Clinton on Sunday.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Holds Off on Endorsing Hillary Clinton for President
leadPara: Appearing on NBC’s “Meet the Press,” Mayor Bill de Blasio said he would wait until learning more about his former boss’s economic platform.
abstract: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio, appearing on NBC's Meet the Press, repeatedly declines to endorse Hillary Rodham Clinton following announcement of her presidential bid; choice is surprising given close relationship between de Blasio and Clinton, who has nurtured his political career.

headline: Group Spells Out  5-Year Plan to Build Liberal ‘Infrastructure’
abstract: While Hillary Rodham Clinton was kicking off her very long-awaited presidential bid on one side of the country on Sunday, dozens of deep-pocketed liberal donors were meeting on the other side to ponder a progressive resurgence.

headline: It Takes a Party
leadPara: The 2016 election will be about ideologies, not individuals, despite much media attention to the latter.
abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column argues that despite excessive media attention, personalities of candidates in the 2016 presidential race are relatively unimportant; contends that what truly matters is enormous ideological gulf between the two parties; examines outlook for nation under a Republican and Democratic president.

headline: Some Parents Oppose Standardized Testing on Principle, but Not in Practice
leadPara: Even parents who are uncomfortable with the exams are discovering that it is hard to push the button on the nuclear option — refusing to have their own children take them.
abstract: Many parents in New York City who oppose state standardized testing are uncomfortable with idea of their children refusing to take them.

headline: BlackRock’s Chief, Laurence Fink, Urges Other C.E.O.s to Stop Being So Nice to Investors
leadPara: Laurence D. Fink, chief of BlackRock, the world’s largest asset manager, warns of harm in dividends and stock buybacks.
abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin DealBook column observes BlackRock chief executive Laurence D Fink is informing chief executives of nation's 500 biggest companies they are hurting both their firms and investors by paying dividends and buying back stock; points out Fink is bucking trend by saying such moves are being done at expense of investing in 'innovation, skilled work forces or essential capital expenditures.'

headline: Wage Effort Poses Test for Clinton Campaign
leadPara: A nationwide strike may provide the first test for the Clinton campaign at managing the desire of voters and party activists for an aggressive approach to mitigating income inequality.
abstract: Daylong nationwide strike by fast-food and other low-wage workers for $15-an-hour minimum wage may offer first test for Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign at managing voters' and activists' calls for aggressive moves on income inequality; Clinton has offered few details on dealing with economic issue.

headline: In Perception Primary, It’s Folksy Hillary Clinton vs. Statesmen-Looking Jeb Bush and Marco Rubio
leadPara: Republican candidates like Mr. Rubio and Mr. Bush are honing their leadership credentials while Mrs. Clinton tries to connect with average Americans.
abstract: Political Memo; Democratic and Republican presidential contenders are seeking to alter their public images in differing ways, with Sen Marco Rubio, Wisconsin Gov Scott Walker, Sen Rand Paul and Florida Gov Jeb Bush trying to appear presidential while Hillary Rodham Clinton making attempt at approachability; danger for candidates on both sides lies in appearing phony.

headline: ‘The Fishermen,’ by Chigozie Obioma
leadPara: Guilt and suspicion infect the lives of four carefree brothers in this debut novel.
abstract: Fiammetta Rocco reviews book The Fishermen by Chigozie Obioma.

headline: Review: Magma Plays Prog-Rock at Le Poisson Rouge
leadPara: This French band closed out the United States leg of its global tour at Le Poisson Rouge.
abstract: Jon Pareles reviews performance by Magma, band formed in 1969 by drummer and songwriter Christian Vander, at Le Poisson Rouge.

headline: Bill Arhos, Founder of ‘Austin City Limits,’ Dies at 80
leadPara: Mr. Arhos convinced public broadcasting stations in 1975 that the nation was ready for a TV show devoted to the non-Nashville variety of country.
abstract: Bill Arhos, a guitarist who created the television program Austin City Limits, the longest-running live musical concert show on television, dies at age 80.

headline: De Blasio Seeks Updated Vision From Clinton for 2016
leadPara: Mayor Bill de Blasio says the country has changed significantly since the last time Hillary Clinton was a candidate, “eight long years ago.”
abstract: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio defends his decision not to endorse Hillary Rodham Clinton for president until she takes stand on current issues like income inequality.

headline: Survey Offers Rare Window Into Chinese Political Culture
abstract: A draft research paper finds that China may be divided, much like the United States, into “red” conservative provinces mostly in the poorer rural interior and richer and urbanized “blue” coastal provinces.

headline: In Exile, but Ready to Save Russia
leadPara: We have a global vision, and embrace what's best about the West to help our home country.

headline: Mayor de Blasio, on Midwest Trip, Seeks to Lead a National Shift to the Left
leadPara: Bill de Blasio is seeking to jump-start a movement to promote liberal policies like raising taxes on the rich, but he is facing a backlash from Democrats over his refusal to endorse Hillary Rodham Clinton.
abstract: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio arrives in Midwest for two-day tour of Nebraska and Iowa, where he hopes to jumpstart his mission to lead nation leftward; will promote slate of policies like raising taxes on the rich; some within Democratic party question whether de Blasio has earned right to drive insurgency within party.

headline: In Test for Unions and Politicians, a Nationwide Protest on Pay
leadPara: For activists anticipating the 2016 presidential race, the minimum wage fight, and the challenge it poses to a system they say favors the rich, comes at a pivotal time.
abstract: Protest in more than 200 American cities by fast-food and other low-wage workers for $15-an-hour minimum wage has broad public support but is up against hostile business sector; issue is timely one, as 2016 presidential election is gearing up and it could become first large-scale challenge to an economic system that some see as favoring the wealthy; while many large employers have moved to raise base pay, business groups claim higher wages will lead to less hiring.

headline: When Old Glory Returned to Fort Sumter
abstract: The flag raising was supposed to make April 14, 1865 a joyous day. Events that even marked it differently in the history books.

headline: Clinton Is Said to ‘Love’ de Blasio, Despite Lack of Endorsement
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton has no hard feelings toward Mayor Bill de Blasio for declining to endorse her presidential bid — at least according to Tom Harkin, the former senator from Iowa.

headline: Mayor de Blasio, in Iowa, Cites ‘Rampant Inequality’ in U.S.
leadPara: Mayor Bill de Blasio sounded a lot like the national player he aspires to be, delivering a fiery speech about the dangers of income inequality and calling for a revival of progressive-era politics.
abstract: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio visits Des Moines, Iowa, part of nationwide tour intended to jumpstart national liberal coalition that could influence presidential race; de Blasio's speech at Drake University focuses on dangers of income inequality and plight of middle class.

headline: Education
leadPara: New books by Lani Guinier, Greg Toppo, Fareed Zakaria and Jonathan Zimmerman.
abstract: Kevin Carey reviews books The Tyranny of the Meritocracy: Democratizing Higher Education in America by Lani Guinier, The Game Believes In You: How Digital Play Can Make Our Kids Smarter by Greg Toppo, In Defense of a Liberal Education by Fareed Zakaria and Too Hot To Handle: A Global History of Sex Education by Jonathan Zimmerman.

headline: NYTLNReads | Some of Our Favorite Student Comments on Comedy and Its Limits
abstract: Here are some of our favorite student answers to the question “Are There Topics That Should Be Off-Limits to Comedy?”, as well as a look at how one teacher conducted a class discussion of the issue on Twitter.

headline: Can You Be a Waitress and a Feminist?
leadPara: I put up with sexual harassment for the chance of a good tip.
abstract: Brittany Bronson Op-Ed article considers question of what it means to be feminist while also working as cocktail waitress in Las Vegas casino, where sexual harassment is distressingly common.

headline: Things to Do in Westchester, April 19 to 25, 2015
leadPara: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.

headline: Checking Charlie Hebdo’s Privilege
leadPara: Progressive critics of the murdered cartoonists need to realize that satire isn’t just for “suitable” subjects.
abstract: Ross Douthat Op-Ed column uses critical comments made by cartoonist Gary Trudeau about cartoonists at Charlie Hebdo to underscore disturbing trend in left-leaning circles toward dangerous oversimplification of hierarchies of power and victimhood.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, BERTRAND
leadPara:
FRANK--Bertrand,

passed away on April 15, 2015, in Manhattan from a stroke. Born on November 9, 1919 he was the beloved and most devoted husband of Yvette T. Frank for 44 years. Loving father of Mitchell Frank and caring stepfather of Dr. Stuart Jones and the late Merrell Jones. Cherished grandfather of Briana Frank, Arielle Frank, Dr. Melissa Jones, and Barbara Jones. Dear uncle of Teitelman nieces and nephews. Mr. Frank was the founder in 1946 and president of Bertrand Frank Associates, international consultants to apparel, textile and retail companies. Author of "The Progressive Sewing Machine," "Profitable Merchandising of Apparel" and many other publications. Memorial service is planned.

headline: At Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Ceremony, a Generational Push and Pull
leadPara: Even with a millennial ambassador like Miley Cyrus onstage, the ceremony was about holding up — and keeping a tight grip on — consensus icons of the art form, like the late Lou Reed.
abstract: Generational similarities and divisions are apparent at 30th Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony in Cleveland, with event focused on holding up consensus icons of rock music while attempting to embrace newer performers.

keywords.value: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum

headline: Kanye West, Amy Schumer Shake Up Time 100 Gala
leadPara: Time magazine celebrates its annual list of “The 100 Most Influential People,” with Kim Kardashian, Kanye West and Martha Stewart.
abstract: Time magazine honors annual list of 100 people it considers to be most influential during party at Jazz at Lincoln Center.

headline: Obamacare, Hands Off My Medicare
leadPara: What lies behind the increasing resistance to economic redistribution?

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

headline: New York Philharmonic’s Challenges Go Beyond the Music
leadPara: A major renovation and finding a replacement for Alan Gilbert are just two of the major issues confronting the orchestra.
abstract: New York Philharmonic is bracing for anticipated period of upheaval; will be displaced for two seasons while its aging home at Avery Fisher Hall is renovated; must raise hundreds of millions to pay for renovation and shore up persistently tenuous coffers, and must find someone to succeed music director Alan Gilbert, who is departing in 2017; any of these hurdles is difficult in itself, but facing all simultaneously is daunting.

headline: Democrats Are Rallying Around $12 Minimum Wage
leadPara: Democrats are uniting around a proposal to raise the federal minimum wage to $12 an hour, an issue with considerable popular support in an era of increasing income inequality.
abstract: Democratic Sen Patty Murray plans on introducing minimum wage bill that would increase wage floor from $7.25 to $12 by 2020, effort mirrored in companion House measure to be introduced by Rep Robert C Scott; both have considerable support in Democratic Party, indication of party's intent to focus on issue in 2016 elections.

headline: Cash Flowed to Clinton Foundation Amid Russian Uranium Deal
leadPara: As the Russian atomic energy agency gradually took charge of a company that controls one-fifth of all uranium production capacity in the United States, a stream of cash made its way to the former president’s charitable organization.
abstract: Canadian founders of Uranium One, major producer of nuclear material that would eventually be sold to Russia's state-owned Rosatom, made millions of dollars in donations to Clinton Foundation as deal was pending; donations came during Hillary Clinton's tenure as Secretary of State, and coincided with her department's approval of sale; examination of deal and its security implications has raised serious questions about conflict of interests as Clinton pursues presidential bid.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS)

headline: How Do We Protect New York City’s Pedestrians?
leadPara: Making the streets safer begins by acknowledging that people will walk wherever they damn well please.
abstract: Susan Dominus article examines efforts on part of New York City authorities to redesign traffic intersections as part of Mayor Bill de Blasio's Vision Zero, plan that seeks to reduce pedestrian deaths in the city to zero.

keywords.value: Traffic and Parking Signals and Signs

headline: The Cost of Turkey’s Genocide Denial
leadPara: Reconciliation of Armenians, Kurds and Turks will require a hard look backward in order to move forward.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

headline: Clinton Rules
abstract: Here we go again?

headline: Suddenly, a Police Presence Comes to Brooklyn Bridge Park
leadPara: As a result of gunshots in the park, a car with two officers is now stationed at Pier 2 every day after school, and the 84th Precinct has requested that more officers be assigned there this summer.
abstract: Ginia Bellafante Big City column notes stepped-up police presence at Brooklyn Bridge Park after shooting at Pier 2, only serious crime reported in park's five-year history; park has expanded over years and broad spectrum of visitors now reflects diversity of borough.

headline: Popcast: Kamasi Washington and the West Coast Get Down
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss the tenor saxophonist and his roots in the thriving Los Angeles jazz scene.

headline: Scott Walker, a Pastor’s Son, Runs on Faith as Iowa Beckons
leadPara: Mr. Walker’s lifelong church involvement may be a powerful asset as he positions himself to run for president and focuses on states dominated by evangelical voters.
abstract: Wisconsin Gov Scott Walker makes his most explicit appeal yet to evangelical Christians at event organized by Iowa Faith and Freedom Coalition; Walker's background as son of Baptist preacher and his long involvement in church may give him significant leg up over other Republican candidates.

headline: Finding Liberation in Two Deaths
abstract: I loved my mother and my drinking, but both were limiting my potential.

headline: Speeding in Finland Can Cost a Fortune, if You Already Have One
leadPara: The Finnish “day fine” system, which factors in income when calculating penalties for infractions, is causing a debate in a nation with an egalitarian streak. One millionaire, for example, was fined 54,024 euros (about $58,000) for a traffic ticket.
abstract: Helsinki Journal; $54,024-euro speeding ticket issued to Finnish millionaire Reima Kuisla illustrates extreme example of nation's 'day fine' system, which calculates penalties according to income; incident has spurred debate in Helsinki and throughout country, known for its egalitarian streak, over whether fines amount to form of taxation.

headline: ‘Silicon Valley’ Recap: It’s Not About How Much You Earn
abstract: There’s a new guy in “Silicon Valley,” and he’s awful, which is great.

headline: Pope Francis Steps Up Campaign on Climate Change, to Conservatives’ Alarm
leadPara: An effort by the pope to further the issue of climate change and environmental stewardship is already angering some thinkers on the American right.
abstract: Efforts by Pope Francis to further issue of climate change and environmental stewardship are angering many American conservatives who challenge scientific validity of climate change theories.

headline: Treat All Cypriots Equally
leadPara: It is astonishing that Greek Cypriots enjoy Western political support while the Turkish Cypriot people remain isolated from the world.

headline: Bernard Sanders to Announce Presidential Bid
abstract: Senator Bernard Sanders, the independent from Vermont, plans to run for president as a Democrat, becoming the only official party challenger so far to Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: California Governor Orders New Target for Emissions Cuts
leadPara: Gov. Jerry Brown issued an executive order sharply increasing the state’s already ambitious program to curb greenhouse gas emissions.
abstract: California Gov Jerry Brown issues executive order rapidly increasing state's plan to control greenhouse gas emissions; order, which would require drastic 40 percent reduction in emissions by 2030, is part of Brown's plan to put California on forefront of world's efforts to address climate change.

headline: Doctors Worry Verdict in A.L.S. Murder Case Could Stigmatize the Disease
leadPara: The case of a Wisconsin man with A.L.S. who lawyers argued had dementia and was not responsible in the shooting deaths of his wife and sister-in-law has raised concerns about A.L.S. patients being branded violent.
abstract: Wisconsin jury finds former sheriff's deputy Andrew Steele not legally responsible in shooting deaths of his wife and sister-in-law because he has amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrig's disease; defense claimed he developed dementia from condition and was not guilty due to mental illness; some clinicians worry case may stigmatize ALS patients as being violent.

headline: Bernie Sanders, Long-Serving Independent, Enters Presidential Race as a Democrat
leadPara: The Vermont senator’s candidacy will inject a leftist voice into the contest and provide Hillary Rodham Clinton with her first official rival for the Democratic nomination.
abstract: Sen Bernie Sanders announces that he will enter 2016 presidential race as Democrat, providing Hillary Clinton with her first official rival for party's nomination.

headline: Today in Politics: Sanders Offers Clinton Both a Potential Foil and a Pitfall
abstract: The entrance of Mr. Sanders into the Democratic presidential primary presents Mrs. Clinton, who is working hard to highlight her progressive bona fides, with both potential pitfalls and opportunities.

headline: Bernie Sanders and Calvin Coolidge: A Vermont Tie But Not Much Else
abstract: The outspoken Senator Bernie Sanders is vying do what another Vermonter, Calvin Coolidge, known as silent Cal did: occupy the White House.

headline: Times Reporters Analyze Bernie Sanders’s Presidential Campaign Remarks
leadPara: Two New York Times correspondents, Patrick Healy and Maggie Haberman, discussed Mr. Sanders’s remarks about his priorities for the country and his challenge to Hillary Rodham Clinton for the 2016 Democratic nomination.

headline: Change to a Segregated Monument Is Stymied by a Law Protecting It
leadPara: Greenwood wants to replace memorial plaques that list war dead by race. But state law requires legislative approval, which the city does not have.
abstract: Greenwood, SC, Mayor D Welborn Adams and local American Legion post want to replace plaques that list war dead by race, but state law requires legislative approval, which they do not have.

headline: Review: ‘Latin America in Construction: Architecture 1955-1980’ at MoMA
leadPara: The exhibition recalls a not-so-distant time when architects and governments in the region dreamed big about changing the world for the better.
abstract: Michael Kimmelman reviews Museum of Modern Art exhibition Latin America in Construction: Architecture 1955-1980.

headline: Crime, Clinton and a New Era
leadPara: As the streets of Baltimore erupt in protests, and questions about race, poverty and the prison population tower over the political landscape, the halcyon years of the tough-on-crime Bill Clinton administration look less idyllic.
abstract: News Analysis; urgent debate about race, poverty and prison population, highlighted by street protests in Baltimore, has called into question the tough-on-crime policies initiated under administration of Pres Bill Clinton; Democratic presidential hopeful Hillary Clinton has condemned vicious cycle of poverty and incarceration, implicitly steering Democratic Party away from ideology of her husband's 1994 crime bill.

headline: Police Fire Tear Gas and Water Cannons at Istanbul Protesters
leadPara: Hundreds of people defied a ban on holding May Day celebrations in Taksim Square, a focal point of previous antigovernment protests.
abstract: Hundreds of demonstrators in Istanbul defy ban on May Day rallies and are forcefully dispersed by riot police using tear gas and water canons.

headline: Sorry, Etsy. That Handmade Scarf Won’t Save the World.
leadPara: Online artisan markets may have chic offerings, but they’re not morally superior.
abstract: Op-Ed article by Emily Matchar remarks on success of handmade-goods sites like Etsy, as well as popularity of artisan markets across the country; rejects notion that buying such items impacts social change, when what is really needed is mandatory paid parental leave and subsidized day care.

headline: Cleveland Indians Have Home-Field Advantage on Recycling
leadPara: Progressive Field’s concessions adopt a system that converts food waste to energy.
abstract: Concessions at Progressive Field, home to Cleveland Indians, are transforming food waste into energy and fertilizer at plant run by renewable energy firm Quasar; Environmental Protection Agency says estimated 34 tons of food waste annually is biggest part of landfills, which cause 18 percent of nation's methane emissions.

headline: Hillary Clinton Courts the Democratic Left, but Is Pressured to Take Progressive Stands
leadPara: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s pursuit of the liberal base has been met with desires for assurances that a progressive agenda will be followed to completion.
abstract: Entrance of left-leaning Sen Bernie Sanders into 2016 presidential race could put pressure on Democratic frontrunner Hillary Clinton to be more aggressive in courting liberals than she might have been otherwise.

headline: Bernie Sanders Yells His Mind
leadPara: We now get to spend many months entertaining the idea of a President Bernie, and competition is always good in politics.
abstract: Gail Collins Op-Ed column welcomes announcement by Sen Bernie Sanders, independent of Vermont, of his official candidacy in 2016 race for Democratic presidential nomination; acknowledges Sanders's consistency on issues over time but holds he is too far left to be significant threat to Hillary Rodham Clinton; suggests that his entry should at least keep Clinton on her toes and make race more interesting.

headline: Edward Chambers, Early Leader in Community Organizing, Dies at 85
leadPara: A lapsed seminarian, Mr. Chambers succeeded Saul Alinsky as leader of the social justice umbrella group Industrial Areas Foundation.
abstract: Edward T Chambers, head of social justice group Industrial Areas Foundation, dies at age 85.

headline: Reinvigorating The Chicago Defender, a Historic Print Voice
leadPara: With a new publisher and plenty of news to report, the now-weekly newspaper is seeking to lure new readers with a more empowering narrative.
abstract: Chicago Defender, city's storied black newspaper, is seeking to lure new readers as it seizes on national debate in the wake of civic unrest in Ferguson, Mo, Baltimore and elsewhere; paper emerged as weekly under guidance of new publisher Cheryl Mainor, following financial woes, staff turnover and uncertainties of changing media landscape.

headline: ‘Inequality Is a Choice’
leadPara: The roots of inequality are complex, but our policy decisions play a significant role.
abstract: Nicholas Kristof Op-Ed column asserts that problem of inequality in America, while worsening, is not inevitable and can be subverted via policy decisions; suggests several government policies that could begin to reduce inequality; holds United States is not helpless in face of inequality but thus far has lacked will to tackle it head on.

headline: Dave Goldberg Was Lifelong Women’s Advocate
leadPara: The late chief executive of SurveyMonkey and husband of the Facebook executive Sheryl Sandberg was raised around “woman power” and was an avid supporter of female achievement.
abstract: Friends and family recall life of late SurveyMonkey chief executive Dave Goldberg, husband of Facebook executive Sheryl Sandberg, who died suddenly at age 47; Goldberg was a lifelong women’s advocate, and first major chief executive to spur his wife to become as successful in business as he was.

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: Lean In: Women, Work, and the Will to Lead (Book)

headline: Chinese Leader and Head of Taiwan’s Kuomintang Discuss Economy and Disaster Response
abstract: The two met in Beijing, and the visit by the Taiwanese party leader, Eric Chu, was the first official trip by a head of the party to the mainland since 2009.

headline: McDonald’s Chief Promises Turnaround in a Restructuring
leadPara: Steve Easterbrook, the new chief executive of the fast-food company, spoke of an “urgent need to reset this business” in a video message on Monday.
abstract: McDonald's, confronting falling sales in its largest markets, unveils initial steps of global turnaround strategy; new chief executive Steve Easterbrook announces largely operational changes; first quarter revenue was $5.96 billion, down 11 percent from year-ago quarter.

headline: Wisconsin, Politics and Faith Bind Scott Walker and Paul Ryan
leadPara: As Mr. Walker prepares to begin his campaign for president, his relationship with Mr. Ryan is revealing what kind of candidate he would be.
abstract: Wisconsin Gov Scott Walker, likely 2016 presidential contender on Republican ticket, has a long relationship with Rep Paul D Ryan, and it is increasingly evident that many of Ryan's conservative tax and spending policy ideas underpin Walker's campaign speeches; Ryan could end up playing a role in the cabinet of a Walker administration.

headline: Nicola Sturgeon, Not Running in British Election, May Yet Prevail
leadPara: The leader of the Scottish National Party could emerge from the general election as a national political force, and is eager to use her clout.
abstract: Scottish National Party leader Nicola Sturgeon is seen as emerging from general election cycle as national political force in Britain, leading third-largest bloc of seats in Parliament; 44-year-old feminist has gained prominence in televised debates.

headline: Review: ‘Hold Still,’ Sally Mann’s Memoir, Reveals a Photographer’s Rich Life
leadPara: Ms. Mann holds back little as she uses words and photos to detail her family, the South and more.

abstract: Election victory of left-leaning New Democratic Party in Alberta, Canada, ousts Progressive Conservative Party after 43 years in power; political reversal raises questions about future of oil sands in Alberta, known as Canada's oil country, which were lightly regulated under previous administration.

abstract: Cody Wilson, Texas man ordered by State Dept to remove his plans for a 3-D printable gun from Internet, files suit against department claiming that order violates his free speech rights; suit poses new quandary for free speech law.

headline: Acrimony in Albany as Senate Republicans Stop Effort to Oust Skelos
leadPara: Democrats hoped that by seeking a vote to remove Dean G. Skelos as Senate leader, they would force their Republican colleagues to take a public position on his arrest.
abstract: New York State Democrats walk out of State Senate chamber after Republicans block their effort to remove Dean G Skelos as majority leader; had hoped move would force Republicans to take position on Skelos's arrest on federal corruption charges, but were foiled amid squabbles over parliamentary procedures.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s Latest Budget Won’t Pay for More Police Officers
leadPara: Mayor Bill de Blasio suggested that changes under his administration had already eased the burden on officers’ time, even as crime remained relatively low.
abstract: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio unveils $78.3 billion budget containing proposals to reduce income inequality, but not allowing for hiring more police officers; police spokesman says talks with City Hall will continue.

headline: Obama Scolds Democrats on Trade Pact Stance
leadPara: The president, battling for passage of one of the final initiatives of his presidency, said liberals opposed to the accord were “just wrong.”
abstract: Pres Obama accuses Democrats of intentionally distorting facts on Trans-Pacific Partnership agreement; forceful comments underscore rancor among Democrats over trade and huge challenges Obama faces in rallying his party behind one of the most significant initiatives of his presidency.

headline: The Curious Case of Negative Interest Rates

abstract: Jeb Bush delivered a forceful defense of religious freedom from a secular government, deploring the rise of “coercive federal power” under President Obama that he said was seeking to impose progressive dogma on the country’s faithful.

headline: Despite DNA, the Rapist Got Away
leadPara: When rape kits go untested, the injustice of rape is compounded by the injustice of official indifference.
abstract: Nicholas Kristof Op-Ed column highlights cases of rape kits going untested for decades in Cook County, Ill, to underscore degree to which rapes often are not fully investigated; suggests rapes offer window into issue of law enforcement inequality, where low-income communities, often with large minority populations, are under-served by authorities.

headline: Obama Calls Elizabeth Warren ‘Absolutely Wrong’ on Trade Deal
leadPara: The president said the liberal senator’s warnings about the potential damage of the Trans-Pacific Partnership were nothing more than “hypotheticals.”
abstract: Pres Obama, in online interview, accuses Democratic Sen Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts of being motivated by politics in opposing Pacific trade accord, deepening conflict with his own liberal base.

headline: Campus Debates on Israel Drive a Wedge Between Jews and Minorities
leadPara: Student groups nationwide are proposing that their colleges divest from companies that do business with Israel, a sign that a campaign is gaining traction.
abstract: Student government councils in dozens of American colleges have passed resolutions urging school administrations to divest from companies that many see as helping Israel mistreat Palestinians; resolutions are inspired by Boycotts, Divestment and Sanctions campaign; debates are emotional, with many minorities expressing solidarity with Palestinians, and supporters of Israel, worried that debates are motivated by anti-Semitism and a questioning of legitimacy of Israel itself.

headline: Julie Stein, Adam Freelander

leadPara: Legislation that is scheduled for action Tuesday would allow President Obama to avoid amendments or a filibuster after a Trans-Pacific Partnership deal.

headline: Cuomo’s Push to Raise Wages Lifts Spirits of New York’s Fast-Food Workers
leadPara: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s move to unilaterally increase hourly pay for thousands of workers in the state cheered many who recalled his previous lack of interest in the topic.
abstract: Rachel L Swarns The Working Life column observes new enthusiasm among low-wage workers and their advocates for New York State Gov Andrew M Cuomo, who has proposed plan to unilaterally raise wages in the fast-food industry; notes that many had previously been skeptical of Cuomo, who seemed to dither on issue before taking action; examines proposal.

headline: A Chasm Divides David Cameron and Nicola Sturgeon, Leaders of a Kingdom Still United
leadPara: As early as this week, the prime minister of Britain and the first minister of Scotland will hold face-to-face meetings on granting Scotland greater autonomy.
abstract: Memo from Glasgow; British Prime Min David Cameron and Scottish National Party leader Nicola Sturgeon will meet to discuss additional autonomy for Scotland following election in which Scottish separatists won 56 of Scotland's 59 parliamentary seats, nearly ousting unionist lawmakers; results raise possibility of second referendum on independence, making talks particularly important.

headline: After Illness, Former President Jimmy Carter Ends Trip Monitoring Guyanese Election
leadPara: The former president flew home from the South American country on Sunday after falling ill, the Carter Center, his nonprofit organization, said.
abstract: Former Pres Jimmy Carter's nonprofit organization Carter Center says he ended election-monitoring trip to Guyana early and flew home after becoming sick.

headline: Freed From Coalition, David Cameron Picks Conservative Cabinet
leadPara: The British prime minister kept many senior members of his team in place, and said Boris Johnson, London’s mayor, would join his “political cabinet.”
abstract: British Prime Min David Cameron announces new cabinet; brings on several women with aim of fulfilling campaign promise of having one third of cabinet be women; among appointees are potential successors, as Cameron will likely resign before end of parliamentary term in 2020.

headline: The Trans-Pacific Partnership Trade Deal Explained
leadPara: The giant trade pact, years in the making, has become and a cornerstone of President Obama’s trade policy in his final term.

headline: The Center-Right Moment
leadPara: Across the globe, voters are electing center-right leaders with fairly similar platforms. The notable exception is the United States.
abstract: David Brooks Op-Ed column notes surprising popularity of center-right governments both in United States and abroad; questions why presidential contenders of both parties are ignoring this phenomenon in campaigning, with Hillary Clinton moving to further left and Republicans to further right.

headline: The Great Democratic Crack-Up of 2016
leadPara: They may have a strong presidential candidate, but at every other level, the party’s politicians and activists are fighting to survive — and fighting with one another.
abstract: Democratic party is locked in debate over how to repair its fortunes and appeal to voters, particularly at sub-presidential level, with some arguing for centrist approach and others arguing for swing toward liberal populism in Elizabeth Warren mode; party's identity crisis is embodied by race between Maryland Senate candidates Donna Edwards and Chris Van Hollen.

headline: Hillary Clinton Walks Tightrope as Pressure Grows to Take Stance on Trade Deal
leadPara: Her presidential campaign faces questions about the Trans-Pacific Partnership that are seen as a litmus test of her ability to satisfy liberals.
abstract: Political Memo; Hillary Rodham Clinton is being pressured by liberal Democrats to oppose Pres Obama's Trans-Pacific Partnership, while being pressed by Obama allies to support trade deal, first policy test of Clinton's 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: A.C.L.U., Citing Bias Against Women, Wants Inquiry Into Hollywood’s Hiring Practices
leadPara: The organization will ask state and federal agencies to look into what it calls rampant and intentional gender discrimination in recruiting and hiring of female directors.
abstract: American Civil Liberties Union asks state and federal agencies to investigate gender discrimination in recruiting and hiring female directors by major Hollywood studios, networks and talent agencies; cites anecdotal and statistical evidence showing widespread favoritism toward male directors.

abstract: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio holds rally in Washington, DC, as centerpiece of national tour to promote liberal causes; unveils campaign he calls The Progressive Agenda and expresses belief that liberal ideals are spreading across country.

abstract: It’s part of fighting for the future.

headline: Columbia Examines Its Long-Ago Links to Slavery

abstract: Columbia University students research school's historical relationship with slavery for seminar led by historian Eric Foner; find financial and other links to slave owners and traders, as well as evidence that student body was largely apathetic on issue.

headline: Republican Presidential Candidates Rally Around Flat Tax

abstract: At least four Republicans running in 2016 presidential race have indicated their support for a flax tax, or single rate for everyone, to replace current system, which taxes wealthier people at higher rate on income than less affluent taxpayers; filing would be easier, but rich would pay less, and public support is thin.

headline: ‘One Nation Under God,’ by Kevin M. Kruse

abstract: Michael Kazin reviews book One Nation Under God: How Corporate America Invented Christian America by Kevin M Kruse.

headline: From Senate Sideline, Elizabeth Warren Is Face of Attack on Trade Bill
leadPara: Ms. Warren has become the most conspicuous Democrat opposing President Obama’s Trans-Pacific Partnership but has not been involved in shaping it.
abstract: Sen Elizabeth Warren has become face of Democratic opposition to Trans-Pacific Partnership, despite fact that she has had no official role in crafting its legislative language or in opposing it; Warren has used highly effective public relations strategy to cite her concerns about bill's impact on financial regulations, which has crowded out voices of other Democratic senators who have led legislative opposition to deal.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ and the 1960s as Wild Republican Times
leadPara: For a television show set in a turbulent decade, characters are rarely if ever overtly partisan.
abstract: Ginia Bellafante Critic's Notebook reflects upon ambiguous social and political undertones of 1960s period drama Mad Men, which is concluding its run; notes show rarely expresses specific partisan sensibility, but focuses more on highlighting growing split between moderate and conservative Republicans.

headline: Israel, Palestine and the Boycott Debate on Campus

headline: Clintons Earned $30 Million in 16 Months, Report Shows

headline: Latin American Allies Resist U.S. Strategy in Drug Fight

headline: Do Churches Fail the Poor?

headline: Los Angeles Lifts Its Minimum Wage to $15 Per Hour

leadPara:
CROWELL--Joan Lewisohn.

poet author composer and activist died on Saturday, April 18 at her home in Quogue, New York, surrounded by her children. She was 93. She was the wife of David G Crowell who pre-deceased her six years ago, and the former wife of Sidney Simon the artist who co-founded the Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture while they were married. Joan Lewisohn was born in New York the daughter of Sam A Lewisohn and Margaret Seligman Lewisohn. Her parents marriage joined two members of New Yorks great Jewish families a photo of Mrs. Crowell and her sisters is on the cover of Stephen Birminghams Our Crowd. In the 1960s Mrs. Crowell writing as Joan Simon published two books One was a novel: Portrait of a Father (Athenaeum, 1960) The other Fort Dix Stockade was a nonfiction accounting of the mistreatment of Vietnam War activists She also wrote an English language libretto for Glucks Orpheus and numerous poems published in various journals Several decades later she wrote both the music and librettos of operas including The Bell Witch of Tennessee and The Heights which were performed in concert format She wrote a variety of other music some of which was recorded Her recent poems were published in Poems of Possibilities (Sheep Meadow Press 2008) and Recent Poems (Lulu Press 2012). Joan Lewisohn was a young woman of amusing contradictions Though she told her parents she didn't want to go to college she got her BA from Bennington, where she studied with Francis Fergusson and earned a master's degree in English from NYU where she also taught in the 1940s Having gone to New York's progressive Lincoln School where children had a say in what they studied Mrs. Crowell claimed to have gone no farther in math than fractions Despite that she was the Business Manager of the Partisan Review in the 1940s and the treasurer of the authors union PEN in the 1970s In later years she did all her composing on computers to the astonishment of her children. Those ironies continued throughout her life despite often claiming that she was a loner Joan Crowell had five children 16 grandchildren and step grandchildren and five great-grandchildren who all adored her and on whom she doted. Her family mourns her passing architect son Mark Simon and his wife Penny Bellamy in Branford CT artist daughter Teru in Bennington VT designer manufacturer daughter Rachel Simon and her husband Philippe Labeau in Red Hook NY, artist daughter Nora Simon in Boston MA, and nonprofit executive daughter Juno Duenas and her husband Robert in San Francisco CA along with their numerous progeny. A memorial gathering is being planned for family and friends in New York City in September The family asks that memorial gifts be given to Support for Families http://www.supportforfamilies.org/ or East End Hospice www.eeh.org/

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUGETT, SYLVIA
leadPara: GRUGETT--Sylvia Freeman died May 31, 2015, at the age of 96 in Valhalla, NY. She was predeceased by her beloved husband Eldridge and her sister Doris. Sylvia is survived by her cherished children: son Evan, his wife Carol, and daughter Lucy and her spouse Sally. She is also survived by her adored granddaughters Eva, Jaclyn, and Stephanie and five great-grandchildren. Born in the Bronx, NY, to Samuel and Yetta Freeman, Sylvia graduated from Walton High School and Hunter College. A proud New York liberal, her long professional life reflected her commitment to progressive causes, especially the labor movement. We raise a glass to toast her life, lived with spirit, intelligence, and love.

headline: Running Against Hillary
leadPara: The handful of Democratic challengers to the presumptive Democratic candidate have little room to maneuver, but they can be useful in raising issues.

headline: What Makes a Woman?

headline: Ronnie Gilbert, Bold-Voiced Singer With the Weavers, Is Dead at 88
leadPara: Ms. Gilbert, as a member of the Weavers, helped propel folk music to wide popularity and establish its power as an agent of social change.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMBERT, LEON
leadPara:
LAMBERT--Leon "Lamby."

Died on May 24th at the age of 88 with his loving family nearby. A devoted husband, father, son and friend, Lamby brightened everyone's lives with his sense of humor and big heart. He is survived by Evelyn, his wife of over fifty years; his children Mina, Marc and BJ; their spouses Dayton Clark and Jennifer Beisser; and his grandchildren Isaiah, Mateo and Vero. He was predeceased by his brother Matthew "Mendy" Lambert. Lamby was a real kid of the Bronx, growing up in the Allerton Avenue Coops, a pioneering workers cooperative. A handsome man with a mischievous twinkle in his eye, Lamby was known for his antics, starting from his early roots as a Coopnik and Camp Kinderlander. He was a WWII Navy veteran and a man of peace. A graduate of CCNY with a long career as a civil engineer in Manhattan and Long Island, he always enjoyed learning, taking classes and reading nonfiction and history. Leon will best be remembered for the warmth and affection he bestowed on so many. He was gentle, sensitive, generous, fun-loving and funny, with an enduring political consciousness born from his progressive upbringing. Join us for a memorial to share our joy of having had Lamby in our lives. Sunday, June 28 at 2pm at Stryckers Bay Apts Community Room, 66 West 94th St, NYC. Bring your stories and commemorate a life well lived and a man well loved. We welcome remembrances and photos sent to Evelyn or posted to: www.memorialwebsites legacy.com/Lamby

headline: Pope’s Views on Climate Change Add Pressure to Catholic Candidates
leadPara: A Florida archbishop will press the pope’s climate change message in the hope that it will resonate in particular with Marco Rubio and Jeb Bush.

headline: Suleyman Demirel, Seven Times Turkey’s Prime Minister, Dies at 90

abstract: Suleyman Demirel, seven-time prime minister of Turkey who was twice ousted by military coups and later served as country's president, dies at age 90.

headline: My Choice for President? None of the Above
leadPara: So many presidential candidates. So few daring ideas or trade-offs.
abstract: Thomas L Friedman Op-Ed column expresses broad disappointment with field of presidential candidates; observes each candidate is appealing only to their base, adding to a political polarization that has already done great harm; illustrates range of deep economic, educational and technological challenges that only a president with a principled centrism can properly address.

headline: Can Hillary Clinton Be a Woman of the People?
leadPara: Her campaign is banking on the idea that voters are angrier at the rich than they are at the poor.

headline: Better Judgment
leadPara: What should it take for judges to change their minds?
abstract: Emily Bazelon article observes that judges, whose position depends largely on ability to project air of authority and certainty, are often reluctant to change their minds; notes that such changes of opinion, however, are often necessary, particularly in changing times.

headline: Review: Mahler Chamber Orchestra Careens Across the Centuries at Aldeburgh
leadPara: The composer George Benjamin is this year’s artist in residence at the Aldeburgh Festival, and his influence saturated the orchestra’s weekend concerts.

headline: On Technology in Agriculture, Pope Francis’s Concerns are for Corporate Power, Not G.M.O. Risk
abstract: The pope’s complaints about technology in agriculture, including G.M.O.s, focus on corporate behavior and social impacts, not biological peril.

headline: House Sends Trade Bill Back to Senate in Bid to Outflank Foes

headline: Security Law Suggests a Broadening of China’s ‘Core Interests’

leadPara: The Paul plan promises a big tax cut for everyone, but analyses show it would be a big tax cut for high earners and a wash for for everyone else.
abstract: Editorial refutes presidential candidate Rand Paul's plan to overhaul federal tax system by instituting 14.5 percent flat tax; argues plan would result in estimated loss of between $1 trillion and $15 trillion over decade; adds that it would benefit only wealthiest citizens, while low- and middle-income people would be unaffected or harmed; submits flat tax might be feasible if it is acknowledged as value-added tax and supplemented by progressive fiscal system, but latter is not part of Paul's vision.

headline: The New Old Liberalism
leadPara: Hillary Clinton’s speech was economically naive but politically masterful.
abstract: David Brooks Op-Ed column praises first major economic address delivered by Hillary Rodham Clinton in her bid for Democratic Party's presidential nomination, noting she adopted moderate tone and avoided drift toward far left that is becoming popular in party; posits that speech sounded as if Clinton has been listening to voters' very real concerns; expresses skepticism about Clinton's own faith in government's ability to manage economy, but suggests that she has passed first test of her campaign.

headline: Review: Exploring Captivity in Handel’s ‘Alcina’ and Mozart’s ‘Entführung’ at Aix-en-Provence Festival
leadPara: Each presentation offered an 18th-century work in a 21st-century style, though the results differed markedly.
abstract: James R Oestreich Critic's Notebook submits that updated productions of Handel's Alcina and Mozart's Die Entfuhrung aus dem Serail, at Aix-en-Provence Festival in France, both offer blend of traditional music and progressive staging, with captivity as theme; holds Entfuhrung, whose staging is inspired by Muslim extremist brutality, is particularly provocative.

headline: Re-Re-Re-Reintroducing Hillary Clinton
leadPara: The meticulously managed rollout of a candidate whom voters think they know already.
abstract: Profile of Hillary Clinton, who has struggled throughout much of her political career and in beginning of 2016 presidential run to show American public the human, relatable side of herself.

headline: Bernie Sanders and Third Parties
leadPara: With Bernie Sanders running for the Democratic nomination, the Center for Competitive Democracy asserts the value of the third-party candidate.

headline: At Zappos, Pushing Shoes and a Vision
leadPara: Tony Hsieh, C.E.O. of Zappos, is on an uphill mission to remake the company’s culture by banning the boss.
abstract: Tony Hsieh, longtime chief executive of online merchant Zappos, has introduced his employees to radical self-management system called Holacracy; watching innovation and momentum slow throughout the company as it expanded, Hsieh sought out an approach that would remove layers of stifling bureaucracy, do away with management hierarchies and create dynamic work environment.

headline: Dropping $100 for a Day at Jacob Riis, the ‘People’s Beach’
leadPara: Riis Park in the Rockaways has gone artisanal, part of the upscaling of public recreation space.
abstract: Ginia Bellafante Big City column examines upscaling of public recreation space in New York, noting division of crowds at Jacob Riis beach on western end of Rockaway Peninsula; observes gentrified food concessions on the beach, offering indulgences like oysters and $10 cocktails, are in stark contrast to congregation of families, many black and Latino, grilling far more affordable food behind boardwalk.

headline: N.S.A. Summer Camp: More Hacking Than Hiking
leadPara: The National Security Agency is making sure that middle school and high school students — and some teachers, too — are learning how to hack, crack and defend in cyberspace.
abstract: National Security Agency sponsors dozens of free overnight and day camps around country that aim at introducing middle- and high-school-age students to cyber-security tools and techniques; camps are part of effort to reach out to potential recruits for next generation's cybersecurity workforce.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  BATES, EVE
leadPara:
BATES--Eve 1913 - 2015 Passed away peacefully in her sleep July 16 - 102 years old. Eve Bates was born of immigrant parents, grew up in Jazz Age New York, and became a passionate activist for social and labor causes. She joined Harold L. Oram and associates in pioneering the application of ethical fund-raising techniques to liberal and progressive causes. It became her life-long work and helped shape American society into what it is today. In 1942 she married Ralph Bates, English novelist and Spanish Civil War revolutionary who later became an NYU professor (see The New York Times obit 12/4/2000) They lived in Greenwich Village and on the Greek island of Naxos for decades. Eve Bates died of old age and renal failure. She is survived by her son, Jonathan. There will be a memorial service in mid-September. For further information, contact

batesjonathan@yahoo.com.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNS, CLARA
leadPara:
JOHNS--Clara, MD,

July 18, 1916 - May 18, 2015. Umpqua, Oregon. Dr. Clara Johns, born July 18, 1916 on a family farm in Rockford, Illinois, died May 18, 2015 in Umpqua, Oregon. She was 98. She received her Bachelor's degree from Rockford College, and graduated from the University of Chicago as a medical doctor in 1941, one of the first three women to get medical degrees from the university. She entered the Public Health Service, and served during WWII in Washington, DC and Kansas. Later, Dr. Johns was the first woman to graduate with a Masters of Public Health from Harvard. She married Dr. William A. Hall (deceased) and raised five children. The family moved to the west coast where she pursued her career in medicine. She led a life of service and accomplishment, always aspiring to improve public health. Her interest in progressive politics informed her work to help those in need. During her career in California, she worked as a pediatrician at UCLA at the Santa Clara County Health Department with migrant populations providing preventive health and maternal and child healthcare; with the mentally ill at Agnews State Hospital; as a volunteer at the United Farmworkers clinics in Salinas; and with the Flying Samaritans treating Native Americans on remote tribal lands. She retired from her position as Medical Director of the Home Care program at Kaiser Permanente Medical Center, Santa Clara, CA in 1982, where she also had served as Chief of Staff. Upon retirement she received a commendation from the State of California for her service to the community. After her retirement she enjoyed many years living among the redwoods near Watsonville, CA, and ultimately placed a conservation easement on her beloved property with the Santa Cruz Land Trust for preservation. She loved dogs and flowers, and enjoyed reading, collecting stamps, and music, remembering the songs of her childhood into old age. She spent the last 9 years of her life living with her daughter Marcia along the Umpqua River in Umpqua, OR. We will miss her sense of humor and her amazing memory for songs, poetry recitations, and all other items 'great and small' that she learned in her childhood. She is survived by daughters Diana Hall, (Tim) Mt. View, CA, Dr. Linda Hall (Quentin) Walnut Creek, CA, Dr. Marcia Hall, (Donald) Umpqua, OR, son Jeffrey Hall, JD of Santa Cruz, niece Dr. Sandra Drake (Ray) Menlo Park, CA, nephew Karl Drake, (Carol) Palo Alto, grandchildren Nicholas Noble, (Melia) of Umpqua, OR, Ian and Sara Hall of Santa Cruz, CA, Elise Hall, of New Zealand, their mother, Wendy Molin, of Santa Cruz, CA and great-grandchildren Ariana and Lincoln Noble of Umpqua. Her son Dr. Raney Hall preceded her in death. As Dr. St. Claire Drake, her brother-in-law once inscribed "Dr. Clara - whose lively interest in public affairs and social extensions of the Hippocratic Oath I admire." Her great presence in our lives and the lives of all she served will be greatly missed. Memorial contributions can be made in her name to Doctors without Borders or the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. Memorial Services pending. marciah@jeffnet.org

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, VICTOR
leadPara:
PHILLIPS--Victor Duzerah, Jr

Loving husband of seventy years to Grace (Frysinger), devoted father to Vic, Minta, and Stone, died peacefully July 11th in Greensboro, NC. He is remembered by family and friends for his kindness, generosity, humility and intellect. First and foremost, Victor was a family man, always providing loving care and encouragement. Deflecting attention from himself, he focused on others' pursuits. His introspective shyness and quiet thoughtful nature delighted in Grace's gregarious ways. A classic case of "opposites attract" sustained a long marriage. Known for his dry wit and cluttered desk, Victor was once asked by "neatnik" Grace why he never learned to "clean up after his own mess," an early lesson taught to her kindergarten students. He replied, "I never went to kindergarten." Last year, as Grace's progressive dementia necessitated memory care in separate quarters, Victor visited her three times daily-- his life's purpose. Born on New Year's Day, 1919 to Victor and Annie Phillips, Victor Jr. grew up fourth of six children on a farm near Waxahachie, TX. A child of the Great Depression, he learned early lessons in self- sufficiency, discipline and empathy. Childhood years spent without electricity inspired his lifelong interest in electronics. Early on, Victor built his own crystal radio set, hi-fi stereo, even a television. His gifted mind thrilled at the beauty of calculus and the power of words. He enjoyed classic literature, daily crossword puzzles and e-mailing favorite wordlists to his grandchildren. At 63, he joined the new computer revolution. Well into his 80's, he was the go-to-man for all things cyber for his children and digitally-challenged friends. Following coronary by-pass surgery at age 70, he embraced exercise. He took diurnal walks, undeterred by inclement weather. With increasing age, he switched his daily routine to a NuStep machine, pedaling until the week he died. Victor was also an early champion of psychotherapy, talking openly of its life-enhancing benefits in managing his anxiety, helping to de-stigmatize mental health care for others. An Army Veteran of World War II, Victor sustained a shrapnel injury in the Battle of the Bulge resulting in lifelong paralysis of his right arm. He talked about this significant life change in a 1997 father-son interview on Dateline NBC. In a body cast, he married Grace, June 5th, 1945. Victor attended the University of Texas, Austin, Chemical Engineering, BS, and Chemistry, MA, 1951. He was a Monsanto chemical engineer, 1950-1982. In 1965, the family moved from Texas City, TX to suburban St. Louis, where Victor was a founding member of St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Ellisville, MO. Former rector Howard Park remembers him for his unfailing humor and unwavering gratitude for the gift of divine grace. Rev. Park noted Victor's formulation of a guiding spiritual principle, "Grace is the solution in which faith can grow." Victor is survived by his wife, Grace, three children, Victor D. Phillips, III, PhD of Milwaukee, WI (wife Mai), Minta Phillips, MD of Julian, NC and Stone Phillips of New York, NY, Broadcast Journalist (wife Debra), five grandchildren, Anisa Asakawa (husband Nick), Streeter, Catherine, Ben, Chiara, two cousins, five nieces and three nephews. A memorial service will be held at St. Martin's Church, 11am, August 29th, 2015. In lieu of flowers, please send memorial donations to The Alzheimer's Foundation www.alzfdn.org or Fisher House supporting wounded veterans and their families (fisherhouse.org).

leadPara: BATES--Eve 1913 - 2015 Passed away peacefully in her sleep July 16 - 102 years old. Eve Bates was born of immigrant parents, grew up in Jazz Age New York, and became a passionate activist for social and labor causes. She joined Harold L. Oram and associates in pioneering the application of ethical fund-raising techniques to liberal and progressive causes. It became her life-long work and helped shape American society into what it is today. In 1942 she married Ralph Bates, English novelist and Spanish Civil War revolutionary who later became an NYU professor (see The New York Times obit 12/2000) They lived in Greenwich Village and on the Greek island of Naxos for decades. Eve Bates died of old age and renal failure. She is survived by her son, Jonathan. There will be a memorial service in mid-September. For further information, contact batesjonathan@yahoo.com. 1/3

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEONE, RICHARD
leadPara:
LEONE--Richard C.

Former president of the Century Foundation and a past chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, died on Thursday, July 16. He was 75 years old. He was being treated for Parkinson's disease and was recently diagnosed with prostate cancer. Born in Webster, New York in 1940, Dick Leone spent the bulk of his career in public service. A graduate of the University of Rochester, he earned a Masters degree and a PhD at Princeton's Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs. A pragmatic progressive whose views were forged during the Kennedy era, Leone worked on many local and national campaigns. One of his proudest moments was working as an advance man on Robert Kennedy's presidential campaign in Oregon. He also worked on presidential campaigns for George McGovern, Walter Mondale, Michael Dukakis and Bill Bradley. In the '60s, he was executive director of the White House Task Force on The Cities. In addition, Leone managed Brendan Byrne's two successful campaigns for Governor of New Jersey, in 1973 and 1977. From 1974 to 1977, Leone was state treasurer of New Jersey. In 2005, he served as chairman of Governor Jon Corzine's transition committee. Leone served as a commissioner of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and was chairman of the Port Authority from 1990 to 1994. From 1989 to 2011, he was president of the Century Foundation (formerly Twentieth Century Fund), a public policy think tank. Leone steered the foundation to concentrate on such issues as inequality and civil liberties and he fought against attempts at privatizing Social Security. Leone's private sector jobs included working as President of the New York Mercantile Exchange and a managing director at Dillon Read & Co. He has long been a director/trustee of multiple funds at Dreyfus Corp. and serves on the board of the Center for American Progress. Burial is private, but a memorial service will take place in Princeton, New Jersey in September. He is survived by his wife, Meg Cox Leone; his children Kate Leone and Max Leone, and his granddaughter Lucy Kirschner, as well as his sister Sandra Leone Thomas Brooks and first wife, Anita Leone. As well as many nieces, nephews and cousins. Those wishing to honor his memory can consider donations to New Jersey Policy Perspective or the Michael J. Fox Foundation.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIKEL, THEODORE
leadPara:
BIKEL--Theodore.

Partners for Progressive Israel mourn the passing of Theodore Bikel, Board Chairman (2005-present) and inspiration for peace and human rights in the Middle East. All knew Theo as a great performing artist; we knew him as a dynamic social activist and a powerful voice for justice, dignity and peace for Israel, its neighbors and the world. His deep love for Israel was firmly rooted in the Zionist movement. No one was a more articulate advocate for a two-state solution. Theo will continue to light our way with his example of tikun olam, healing the world. We remember his great warmth, humor and vibrant presence. Partners for Progressive Israel has established the Theodore Bikel Fund for Peace and Social Justice to continue his dedicated activism for a secure, democratic Israel and a better world.

headline: The Minimum-Wage Muddle
leadPara: Mandates for better pay will certainly help some people, but hurt some, too.
abstract: David Brooks Op-Ed column highlights research undercutting Democrats' assertion that compelling businesses to raise minimum wage has few drawbacks, noting claims that raising minimum wage does not cost jobs and that it is effective in fighting poverty may be inaccurate; warns that raising minimum wage is not without its own costs.

He was being treated for Parkinson's disease and was recently diagnosed with prostate cancer. Born in Webster, New York in 1940, Dick Leone spent the bulk of his career in public service. A graduate of the University of Rochester, he earned a Masters degree and a PhD at Princeton's Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs. A pragmatic progressive whose views were forged during the Kennedy era, Leone worked on many local and national campaigns. One of his proudest moments was working as an advance man on Robert Kennedy's presidential campaign in Oregon. He also worked on presidential campaigns for George McGovern, Walter Mondale, Michael Dukakis and Bill Bradley. In the '60s, he was executive director of the White House Task Force on The Cities. In addition, Leone managed Brendan Byrne's two successful campaigns for Governor of New Jersey, in 1973 and 1977. From 1974 to 1977, Leone was state treasurer of New Jersey. In 2005, he served as chairman of Governor Jon Corzine's transition committee. Leone served as a commissioner of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and was chairman of the Port Authority from 1990 to 1994. From 1989 to 2011, he was president of the Century Foundation (formerly Twentieth Century Fund), a public policy think tank. Leone steered the foundation to concentrate on such issues as inequality and civil liberties and he fought against attempts at privatizing Social Security. Leone's private sector jobs included working as President of the New York Mercantile Exchange and a managing director at Dillon Read & Co. He has long been a director/trustee of multiple funds at Dreyfus Corp. and serves on the board of the Center for American Progress. Burial is private, but a memorial service will take place in Princeton, New Jersey in September. He is survived by his wife, Meg Cox Leone; his children Kate Leone and Max Leone, and his granddaughter Lucy Kirschner, as well as his sister Sandra Leone Thomas Brooks and first wife, Anita Leone. As well as many nieces, nephews and cousins. Those wishing to honor his memory can consider donations to New Jersey Policy Perspective or the Michael J. Fox Foundation. 1/3

headline: Is There Such a Thing as ‘Ethical Cheating’?
leadPara: An online dating entrepreneur thinks an open mind is the ticket for those who plan to be unfaithful and are willing to tell their spouse ahead of time.
abstract: Brandon Wade, founder of website OpenMinded, which caters to individuals and couples looking for romance outside their marriages, has become advocate for what he calls 'ethical cheating.'

headline: Texas County’s Racial Past Is Seen as Prelude to Sandra Bland’s Death
leadPara: The area where Ms. Bland graduated from college, returned for a job and later died has joined a list of places in America where assumptions of racial progress have been upended.
abstract: Legacy of racial disparities and injustice in Waller County, Tex, has catalyzed deep suspicions about events leading to arrest and subsequent suicide of black woman Sandra Bland in jail cell; county has history of disenfranchisement and racial violence, though some residents say much has improved in recent decades; Bland's death, following other prominent deaths of African-Americans after confrontations with law enforcement, has prompted many to parse details for evidence of bias.

headline: Howard Rumsey, 97, Dies; Musician Invigorated West Coast Jazz Scene
leadPara: As leader of the Lighthouse All-Stars in Hermosa Beach, Calif., Mr. Rumsey helped popularize the notion of a progressive West Coast jazz scene in the 1950s.
abstract: Howard Rumsey, entrepreneur and jazz bassist who led Lighthouse All-Stars and thus helped popularize idea of progressive West Coast jazz scene in 1950s, dies at age 97.

headline: Should We Fear the Political ‘Crazies’?
leadPara: When John McCain referred to people who attended an anti-immigration rally as "crazies,” he was trying to marginalize supporters of Donald Trump. But is the political status quo any saner?
abstract: Mark Leibovich First Words column examines tendency of politicians to dismiss opponents and dissenters by calling them 'crazy'; submits word, which points to deviation from political mainstream, is evolving from pejorative to compliment that suggests passion, individuality and risk-taking.

headline: Suicide on Campus and the Pressure of Perfection
leadPara: Kathryn DeWitt had put on her Penn Face. But living up to expectations — her own and others’ — was just too much. Dying seemed the only way out. It wasn’t.
abstract: University of Pennsylvania student Kathryn DeWitt discusses how pressure to live up to high expectations and perceived standards led her to consider suicide; serious mental health issue with increasing rates among 15-24 year-olds is motivating higher education administrators to create programs to prevent suicide by building emotional resiliency.

headline: Review: ‘Do No Harm,’ a Neurosurgeon’s Tales
leadPara: In a complex and evocative memoir, the British neurosurgeon Henry Marsh confronts uncertainty, bureaucracy and his own mistakes.
abstract: Dr Abigail Zuger reviews book Do No Harm: Stories of Life, Death, and Brain Surgery by Dr Henry Marsh.

headline: Netflix Offers Expanded Maternity and Paternity Leave
leadPara: The company said it was offering unlimited leave for new mothers and fathers for one year after the birth or adoption of a child.
abstract: Netflix initiates unlimited leave policy for new mothers and fathers in first year after birth or adoption of child, policy that is far more generous than what is offered at most large American corporations; employees will receive full pay under plan, as well as other benefits like part-time work upon return; company cites need to retain top talent.

headline: Oklahoma Acts to Limit Earthquake Risk at Oil and Gas Wells
leadPara: A roughly 40-mile-long stretch that includes some 23 wells has experienced a dramatic increase in earthquakes in the last two years.
abstract: Regulators in Oklahoma have directed energy companies to limit disposal of wastewater from oil and gas extraction in wells across roughly 40-mile stretch of land that has experienced dramatic increase in number of earthquakes since  production boomed in 2010; seismologists attribute quakes to lubricating effect of wastewater, but tremor epidemic is not yet fully understood.

headline: Réunion Debris Is Almost Surely From Flight 370, Officials Say
leadPara: Experts who examined the aircraft part found last week have “very strong presumptions” that it came from a Malaysian Boeing 777 that vanished in 2014.
abstract: Malaysian officials assert plane piece found on Reunion Island, France, belongs to Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, which disappeared in March, 2014; experts from Boeing and National Transportation Safety Board ask for more analysis since modifications to part found do not match airline's  maintenance records; debris lacks unique identification number, making positive identification difficult.

headline: Seeing Likely Nominee, Hillary Clinton Hits Jeb Bush Hard
leadPara: Mrs. Clinton’s aides, for the most part, believe Jeb Bush will win the Republican nomination, so she is jabbing at him on issues where they think he is vulnerable.
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton, sensing likelihood that Jeb Bush will capture 2016 Republican nomination, assails Bush during Colorado appearance; tactic allows Clinton to shift focus to policy rather than defending herself from Republican criticism on issues ranging from her personal email to Clinton foundation.

headline: Senate Report Cites I.R.S. Mismanagement in Targeting of Tea Party Groups
leadPara: A report released by the bipartisan panel said the Internal Revenue Service improperly targeted conservative groups seeking tax-exempt status but it did not suggest that any laws were broken.
abstract: Senate investigation finds mismanagement at IRS resulted in it improperly targeting conservative groups seeking tax-exempt status; report stops short of suggesting laws were broken; Republicans claim treatment of groups was politically motivated, assertion Democrats refute.

headline: Lessons of Yonkers From David Simon’s ‘Show Me a Hero’
leadPara: A battle over affordable housing, race and class in Yonkers in the 1980s offers some lessons for battles being fought in New York City.
abstract: Ginia Bellafante Big City column argues HBO broadcast of David Simon documentary Show Me a Hero, about race and class tensions in Yonkers in 1980s, coincides with modern debate in New York City over economic and racial integration of neighborhoods.

headline: Factors Unrelated to Driving Can Affect Car Insurance
leadPara: Many insurers also use a variety of other data, like marital status, as well as a version of credit score, to set rates.
