leadPara: Mixing street smarts, activism and her Muslim identity, Linda Sarsour has become a political force and is setting her sights on New York’s City Council.
abstract: Linda Sarsour, political activist fighting to win rights and reduce stigma surrounding New York City's Muslim population, is using street savvy, honed in a Brooklyn upbringing, wide-ranging connections and her Muslim identity in her quest; Sarsour has set her sights on winning seat on City Council.

headline: Bernie Sanders, After Call From Obama, Announces Support for Iran Deal
abstract: Bernie Sanders, after a phone call from the president, said he would support the nuclear deal with Iran on Friday, a day after another Jewish Democrat in the Senate, Chuck Schumer, said he would oppose it,

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Review: Netflix’s Not So ‘Unlimited’ Benefits
leadPara: Two technology journalists from The New York Times discuss the week’s developments, including parental-leave policies in Silicon Valley.

headline: Similarities Aside, Bernie Sanders Isn’t Rerunning Howard Dean’s 2004 Race
leadPara: Both Democrats from Vermont caught a populist wave, but there are crucial differences between the men and between their eras.
abstract: Sen Bernie Sanders's presidential campaign recalls in both tone and theme candidacy of Howard Dean in 2004; ways Sanders differs from Dean, like his focus on income inequality and impact of money on politics, as well as degree to which he has shown discipline on campaign trail, could mean that he will avoid Dean's fate, which was to fade in popularity after Iowa caucuses.

headline: 1965: Friction Between Singapore and Malaysia Intensifies
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Some predicted that the federation would be torn apart in 1965.

headline: Failing Patients With Heart Failure
leadPara: Doctors still aren’t very good at easing an end that can be very difficult.
abstract: Op-Ed article by Dr Haider Javed Warraich observes that despite marvelous progress in treating heart disease, doctors are still woefully behind in providing quality end-of-life care to heart patients; calls for new research and training to help doctors better deal with terminal cases, and to alleviate suffering  from symptoms like breathing problems; argues that more heart patients, even those under hospice care, should be allowed to die in their own homes.

headline: Capitalists, Arise!: Q. & A. With Peter Georgescu
leadPara: The author of a Sunday Review article arguing that capitalists must address rising income inequality responds to reader comments.

headline: State by State, Democratic Party Is Erasing Ties to Jefferson and Jackson
leadPara: Driven by a desire for racial and gender inclusion, activists are removing the names of Thomas Jefferson and Andrew Jackson from political dinners.
abstract: Democratic activists in several states are removing names of Thomas Jefferson and Andrew Jackson from party gatherings, saying men's legacies are at odds with party as it seeks greater racial and gender inclusion.

headline: Donors Descend on Schumer and Others in Debate on Iran
leadPara: The passions of big contributors — and their ability to change a candidate’s fortunes — are a keenly felt undercurrent to the debate over the fate of President Obama’s nuclear deal with Iran.
abstract: Wealthy political donors are lobbying both for and against Iran nuclear accord in bid to influence undecided Democrats and to sway Sen Chuck Shumer, who opposes deal; opinions of big contributors and their ability to influence election outcomes for lawmakers are strongly felt undercurrent in debate over Iran.

headline: A Data Dinosaur, Tennis Tries an Analytic Approach
leadPara: New tablets containing advanced statistics are being tested at some WTA tournaments, raising questions about how they might alter the player-coach dynamic.
abstract: Bank of the West Classic is first WTA tennis event in which coaches and players are issued iPads that provide nearly real-time data about opponents during games; analysis of data may prove to be important factor in future matches and may change nature of on-court coaching, which has traditionally been prohibited.

headline: Is Hillary Clinton Really in Danger of Losing the Primary?
leadPara: Her favorability ratings are way down, but her position remains very strong. Here’s why.
abstract: The Upshot; many analysts and media outlets have emphasized Hillary Rodham Clinton's unfavorable ratings, but damage to her candidacy for president has been overstated and polls show her position remains strong.

headline: Top Hillary Clinton Donor Clarifies Stance on Iran Nuclear Deal
abstract: A top donor to Hillary Rodham Clinton who came out against the nuclear agreement between Iran and six world powers says his comments about the deal were taken “out of context.”

headline: With $350 Billion Plan, Hillary Clinton Prods Rivals on Student Debt
leadPara: Mrs. Clinton’s ambitious plan to reduce debt in higher education has put pressure on her campaign opponents to propose their own solutions to an intractable problem.
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton's ambitious $350 billion plan to cut higher education debt is opening new front in 2016 presidential campaign, and putting pressure on her opponents; both Republican and Democratic candidates are responding to Clinton's proposal by outlining their own plans to reduce student debt and cut soaring college costs.

headline: King of the Sand Castle
leadPara: A modernist sand sculptor, Calvin Seibert spends up to four days a week during the summer at Rockaway Beach in Queens, mixing Cubist and Brutalist elements in his creations.
abstract: Corey Kilgannon Character Study column profiles Calvin Seibert, sand castle artist whose creations at Rockaway Beach, Queens, reflect his love of modernist design.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Woo Democrats at Iowa Dinner
abstract: The annual Wing Ding Dinner here delivered on its name Friday night as four Democratic presidential candidates tried to excite a crowd of Iowa voters by attacking their Republican counterparts.

headline: Messes Pile Up for de Blasio in 2nd Year
leadPara: Many allies are wondering how Mr. de Blasio, a seasoned political operative, allowed problems to add up in his second year in office.
abstract: Allies of New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio are increasingly concerned about his rocky second year in office, and fret privately that his administration has not given more fanfare to his accomplishments; de Blasio's image has been bruised by perceived missteps, with 44 percent of New Yorkers disproving of his performance in latest poll.

headline: Job Inequality for Latinos in New York
leadPara: The Campaign for Fair Latino Representation writes that the mayor’s continuing failure to address the problem will cost him Latino support.

headline: Lobbying Fight Over Iran Nuclear Deal Centers on Democrats
leadPara: The efforts represent a gritty summertime fight unusual in the annals of foreign policy debates with major implications for President Obama’s legacy.
abstract: Pres Obama is lobbying members of Congress from his own party to support nuclear deal with Iran even from his family vacation in Martha's Vineyard; personal efforts are part of larger push to enlist Democrats' support.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOCKETT, SONYA
leadPara:
DOCKET NWACHUKWU--

Sonya. Sonya Denise Dockett Nwachukwu, Esq., 52, was born on March 3, 1963 in Detroit, Michigan to the late Theresa Ann Dockett and the late Preston Baldwin. She was raised by her grandmother Theresa Dockett. Sonya peacefully departed her earthly life on Wednesday August 5, 2015. Sonya leaves to cherish her memory her beloved husband, Anthony, their children, Anthony Chinedu and Delaney Adanna, of Avon, CT her sister Patrice Pickens of Detroit, MI, her grandmother Theresa Dockett of Detroit, MI, a dearly loved uncle, Donald Dockett of Killen, TX, her cherished in-laws, as well as a host of aunts, uncles, nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. Sonya completed her primary education in the Detroit public school system, where she dreamed big and had aspirations of being an attorney. That spirit to succeed was recognized by a mentor who introduced her to Outward Bound, paving the way to an academic scholarship to Bowdoin College where she successfully obtained a Bachelor of Arts degree. Sonya went on to attend the University Of Maryland School Of Law where she served as the Editor-in-Chief, Maryland Journal of International Law and Trade and Treasurer, Black Law Students Association. She was also a teaching assistant at the law school and interned with the United States Attorney's Office Southern District of New York, Civil Division. Upon receiving her Juris Doctor degree, Sonya was recognized by the faculty with the William P. Cunningham Award given to the graduate who achieves the highest average for scholarship. Sonya was admitted to the Connecticut State Bar in 1990 and began her professional career as in-house Counsel at Aetna. She went on to join ConnectiCare in 2000 as Legal Counsel where she continued to assume progressive roles of responsibility to Vice President and Associate General Counsel. She later resigned in 2009 to devote her energies to her family and her philanthropic passions. A private funeral will be held to honor Sonya's life. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to: Outward Bound Scholarship Program, Attn: Development, 4 Airline Drive, Suite 202, Albany, NY 12205 or at: www.outwardbound.org/ give-back/donate/. The Vincent Funeral Home of Simsbury, CT is caring for the services. Please visit Sonya's Book of Memories at: vincentfuneralhome.com for online condolences.

headline: Mile Mrksic, a Serb Army Officer Convicted of War Crimes, Dies at 68
leadPara: Mr. Mrksic was serving a 20-year prison sentence for his part in the 1991 killings and torture of more than 200 people during the Balkan wars.
abstract: Mile Mrksic, a Serbian former army official sentenced to 20 years in prison by a United Nations tribunal for his role in the torture and death of over 200 people in Croatia during 1991 Balkan Wars, dies at age 68.

headline: Disagreeing With President, Hillary Clinton Says She Opposes Drilling in Arctic Ocean
leadPara: “The Arctic is a unique treasure,” Mrs. Clinton wrote in a signed Twitter post. “Given what we know now, it’s not worth the risk of drilling.”
abstract: Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton, in rare disagreement with Pres Obama, says she is against drilling for oil and gas in Arctic Ocean; comments come one day after White House approves exploration off Alaska coast.

leadPara: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

abstract: President Obama remains on vacation, hoping things stay as unexciting as possible. while several Republican presidential candidates are heading to New Hampshire to talk education.

headline: Hard Climb Awaits Sebastian Coe, New President of I.A.A.F.
leadPara: Sebastian Coe was elected president of the International Association of Atlhetics Federations on Wednesday in Beijing and set out his ambitions, including an assault on doping.
abstract: Christopher Clarey On Track and Field column notes election of Sebastian Coe as president of the International Association of Athletics Federations; holds Coe's biggest challenge will be putting end to widespread and systematic doping  in order to bring credibility back to sport with waning support worldwide.

abstract: Bipartisan effort to undo many provisions of 1994 Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act that Vice Pres Joe Biden helped create could pose obstacle to his potential presidential bid; Biden would need to demonstrate how his views have shifted along with changing public attitudes toward race and criminal justice.

headline: What Is Britain’s Labour Party For?
leadPara: With Jeremy Corbyn ahead in the leadership race, we’re seeing a political movement unable to find new purpose.

leadPara: At a camp for girls, a teenager finds herself infatuated with an older counselor.
abstract: Vera Brosgol reviews young adult book Honor Girl by Maggie Thrash.

headline: Challenging Mayor de Blasio Over Times Square Plazas
leadPara: The idea of ripping up the pedestrian spaces and forcing people to dodge traffic again runs headlong into a policy to improve safety.
abstract: Michael Kimmelman Critic's Notebook offers suggestions for how New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio might tackle problem of topless women and others who seek tips for posing for photos with tourists in Times Square without tearing up pedestrian plazas.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREINDEL, SONIA
leadPara: BREINDEL--Sonia, daughter of Meir and Dina Weissenberg (nee Lunevitch), sister of Sasha Weissenberg, died on September 2, 2015. She was 92. Sonia was born in Luxembourg and survived the Holocaust, escaping from internment camps, hiding in Marseille, before eventually fleeing to Switzerland with her mother. Her father perished at Auschwitz; her brother disappeared. Sonia trained as an interpreter in Geneva, and worked for O.R.T. in Paris, before coming to New York in 1952. There she met and fell in love with Joseph Breindel, an OB-GYN, originally from Zablotow, a small town in what is now Ukraine. They married and had two children, Eric (born 1955), a journalist, who died in 1998, and Monique (born 1954), a doctor. In New York, Sonia worked as an interpreter (she spoke Italian, French, German and English), progressive educator (she received her BA from Goddard and her Masters from Bank Street), gallery assistant, and in recent years as a volunteer at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. More importantly, she was passionate about the arts and culture -- music (she had a beautiful voice); opera; paintings; sculpture; theater; and literature -- and a world traveler. Sonia was also an adoring and adored mother and grandmother, quintessential New Yorker (for all that she was also quite European), and perpetual intellectual sparring partner. Sonia, the Queen of Sheba, is survived by her daughter, Monique, her son-in-law Jonathan, her three grandchildren, Hannah, Naomi and Sarah Rose, and friends and family of all ages, who loved hervery much and will miss her tremendously.

leadPara: The action signaled the determination of the administration of Gov. Jerry Brown to press forward with an aggressive environmental agenda through the regulatory process rather than by legislation.
abstract: California's Air Resources Board approves cut to carbon pollution from gasoline and diesel fuels that will force oil producers to reduce amount of amount of carbon from transportation fuels 10 percent by 2020; approval, coming after rejection of Gov Jerry Brown's plan to drastically cut state's petroleum use by 2030, signals state's determination to aggressively push environmental measures through regulatory process rather than legislation.

headline: Springtime for Liberal Christianity
leadPara: Can Pope Francis revive the fortunes of religious liberalism, and reverse its long decline?
abstract: Ross Douthat Op-Ed column notes Pope Francis' focus on issues dear to the political left has reinvigorated religious liberalism in United States; argues that right-leaning Christians should welcome chance to engage non-secular liberals; notes challenges including left's aversion to supernaturalism and embrace of sexual revolution.

headline: Questions Around Michel Platini Keep FIFA’s Future Murky
leadPara: Although Mr. Platini, widely considered Sepp Blatter’s likely successor, was not implicated by Swiss investigators, that he was interviewed could complicate FIFA’s presidential race.
abstract: Sam Borden On Soccer column speculates on future of FIFA and who might succeed Sepp Blatter as organization's president; notes that most likely candidate, UEFA president Michel Platini, has now been implicated in widening scandal.

headline: Pope Departs, After Showing a Deft Touch
leadPara: Francis demonstrated a nuanced political dexterity, effectively sidestepping the familiar framework of American debate while charting his own broader path.
abstract: Pope Francis departs from Philadelphia, completing his first trip to United States; visit was characterized by Francis's nuanced political dexterity as he addressed nearly every American political issue on his own terms, promoting message of interfaith tolerance and harmony; success of trip could prove to be useful as Francis leads synod of bishops at Vatican to discuss how best to address issues like homosexuality and divorce.

headline: Richard E. Rainwater, Billionaire Texas Dealmaker, Dies at 71
leadPara: Mr. Rainwater made lucrative deals in real estate, entertainment and oil and was a family friend to the Bushes who helped George W. Bush make a modest fortune.
abstract: Richard E Rainwater, Texan mogul and billionaire who amassed fortune through investments in oil, real estate and entertainment and his partnership with George W Bush in Texas Rangers franchise, dies at age 71.

headline: The Deities of Men’s Style
leadPara: Whenever men’s wear designers find themselves in need of inspiration, they turn to the pantheon: Cary Grant, Steve McQueen and Paul Newman.
abstract: Guy Trebay Critic's Notebook observes that male style icons Cary Grant, Steve McQueen and Paul Newman are continual source of inspiration for menswear designers.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAINWATER, RICHARD
leadPara:
RAINWATER--Richard.

Richard Edward Rainwater, philanthropist, legendary and renowned investor, father, husband, mentor, loyal friend and native Texan, passed away September 27, 2015 at his home in Fort Worth. He was 71. Since 2009, Richard fought valiantly against a debilitating and rare neurological disease, Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP). Along with his family's foundation, he spent the latter part of his life funding and actively engaging the international medical community to launch a bold research effort to combat PSP and discover a cure. His significant investment into brain research and neurodegenerative diseases has been called transformational; the goal is to find a treatment for brain-related diseases. Richard is survived by his wife Darla Moore and three children from a prior marriage, Courtney Rainwater, Todd Rainwater and Matthew Rainwater as well as Richard's brother, Walter Rainwater, sister-in-law, Lori and niece, Kelley. He also leaves behind hundreds of friends, business colleagues and people Richard mentored and launched into entrepreneurship as well as the numerous causes he funded and the countless individuals who were deeply touched by his generosity. "A person's legacy is truly who they leave behind," said Darla Moore, "and Richard populated this country with extraordinary talent that he recognized when they were very young. Not many people are generous with their time when mentoring young people. Richard was the exception." Richard has not made any public appearances since 2010. His son, Matthew said his father was the personification of heroism as he battled the illness. "There is an extraordinary untold story about his heroism and bravery as the symptoms worsened. He was determined to embrace every available moment with his loved ones, and he resolved to establish a robust platform for long term research into tauopathies such as PSP and Alzheimer's Disease," said Matthew. "It's another example of him actually 'willing' something into reality." Richard's life was undoubtedly extended because of the extraordinary care he received over the last five and a half years. The family is deeply appreciative of Stephen Boyd, Jerry Harper, Robert Patterson, Eric Thompson, Barry Less, Norman Finley, Rick Castle, Scott Rhode and Bonnie Dears. Their loving, professional and attentive care added much quality to Richard's life. Former President George W. Bush partnered with Richard and Rusty Rose in 1989 to purchase the Texas Rangers MLB club. Mr. Bush issued a statement about his friend. "I was so saddened to learn that my friend Richard Rainwater died this weekend. Richard had a brilliant mind and a generous heart. He was a lot of fun, inspiring to be around, and generous and courageous to the very end. Laura and I send our deepest sympathies to his beloved wife, Darla, and to the children he was so proud of: Matthew, Courtney, and Todd. We also send our condolences to his loyal brother, Walter, and to Richard's family, friends, and staff who loved and cared for him." Those sentiments were echoed across the country from Deepdale Country Club where the flags flew at half-mast to the offices of some of the most powerful people in business to a family that Richard seeded money in order to teach a colleague's children how to give money to worthy charities. Richard's friend Ken Hersh called the loss of his friend immeasurable. "I truly believe he was the godfather of the North American private investment business," Hersh told the News. He created an atmosphere and environment where accomplished, ambitious, entrepreneurial and creative people could work." With all of his business success, family and friends were paramount to Richard, and they describe him as playful. In fact, once he was quoted as saying, "I don't feel like it's in anybody's interest to take themselves and life so seriously that they can't have fun." Richard's "fun" came on the golf course, and he was once a partner in the famed Pebble Beach Golf Club. He also invented a new form of friendly competitive golf for rounds with friends; the game was labeled as "Two Ball." A self-described fitness fanatic, Richard, prior to the onset of his illness, was an avid marathon runner. He also loved motorsports and sponsored cars, most notably a 1957 "muscle car," in competitions. Born June 15, 1944 to Walter J. Rainwater Sr. a wholesale grocer, and Regina Dieb Rainwater, a J.C. Penney sales clerk, Richard treasured his Texas roots. He grew up in his native Fort Worth, graduating from R.L. Paschal High School, and he remained a steadfast Panthers fan. He received his undergraduate degree from the University of Texas and had an MBA from Stanford University. At age 26, Sid Bass, a former classmate, hired Rainwater as an investment manager for the Bass family fortune. He directed the Bass fortune of $50 million into $5 billion between 1970 and 1986. In fact, he assisted Michael Eisner when he was Disney CEO to increase his fortune into billions of dollars. In 1986, Richard started his own firm, Rainwater Inc and successfully acquired stakes in companies such as Columbia/HCA Healthcare, Ensco International, Pioneer Natural Resources, Mid Ocean Limited and Crescent Real Estate Equities. His success as an investor is legendary, prompting The New York Times to describe him this week as a "quiet mover of wealth and power" in the country. Services to celebrate a man whose life can be defined by its optimism, generosity, belief in his loved ones as well as his colleagues and friends will be held Friday, October 2, 2015 at Broadway Baptist Church, 305 W. Broadway Avenue, Fort Worth, Texas at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be offered to the Rainwater Neurological Research Fund, www.cfntx.org/rainwater In addition, the family plans to announce details for a memorial service to be held in New York City on October 27, 2015.

headline: Christophe Lemaire on Building His Brand and Designing for ‘Everyday Quality of Life’
leadPara: The designer and his partner Sara-Linh Tran present their spring/summer 2016 collection — and unveil their Uniqlo collaboration — this week.

headline: Donald Trump Is Not Going Anywhere
leadPara: Where does his political adventure end? “I have no idea. But I’m here now. And it’s beautiful.”
abstract: Donald J Trump has outlasted predictions of his early demise in 2016 presidential race, buoyed by voters' simmering desires for uncomplicated return of American greatness and anger at political class; Trump's defiance of both rules and expectations has left question of his political future wide open.

headline: Trump Tax Plan a Triumph of Showmanship Over Common Sense
leadPara: The plan would greatly reduce the taxes of most business owners, bankers, lawyers and other high income professionals.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Pajama Party
leadPara: With Lena Dunham, the candidate gives us a fresh glimpse of her labored spontaneity.
abstract: Frank Bruni Op-Ed column expresses disappointment with Hillary Rodham Clinton's bid to lighten her image amid lackluster presidential campaign by giving interview to filmmaker Lena Dunham; blames voters' demand that candidates show their informal sides, but asserts Clinton's recent attempt is inauthentic and thus unnecessary.

headline: De Blasio Returning to the National Political Stage
leadPara: Mayor Bill de Blasio, a Democrat, is flying to Washington — his eighth trip there as mayor — to address what is billed as “the largest-ever gathering of progressive lawmakers.”
abstract: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio returns to national political stage, encouraging support of Wisconsin Democrat Russell D Feingold's senate campaign, and sponsoring presidential forum in Iowa; planned trip to Washington, DC, will include meeting with Secretary of Housing Julian Castro, address to conference of liberal state legislators and meeting of United States Conference of Mayors, group in which de Blasio has taken active role.

headline: Pacific Trade Deal Talks Resume, Under Fire From U.S. Presidential Hopefuls
leadPara: The proposed agreement, which would be a legacy achievement for President Obama, has had trade ministers deadlocked over pharmaceutical drug protections, auto exports and other matters.
abstract: Officials from United States and 11 Pacific nations resume trade deal negotiations; significant differences between participants persist, and prospects have also been harmed by slew of criticism from American presidential candidates.

headline: New York Today: Introducing Hurricane Joaquin
leadPara: Thursday: A possible hurricane ahead, rainy weather, and a Bronx deli.

headline: Sentencing Overhaul Proposed in Senate With Bipartisan Backing
leadPara: The long-awaited measure would cut mandatory prison sentences for nonviolent offenders and promote more early release from federal prisons.
abstract: Bipartisan group of senators announce broad criminal justice reform measure, which they describe as historic federal justice overhaul and example of way compromise can lead to effective governance; legislation would reduce mandatory prison sentences for nonviolent offenders and institute programs to educate prisoners, among other measures.

abstract: Stepping back to try to puzzle out the pope.

headline: India Announces Plan to Lower Rate of Greenhouse Gas Emissions
leadPara: India, the world’s third-largest carbon polluter, was the last major country to issue its plan before a major summit meeting in Paris in December.
abstract: India announces long-term plan to reduce greenhouse gas emissions while developing sustainable energy sources; world's third-largest polluter, who has resisted curbing fossil-fuel use out of fear of impacting country's economic development, announces plan ahead of December Paris climate summit; experts praise plan yet warn collective global efforts still fall short of meaningful targets.

headline: Turning U.N. Development Goals Into Reality
leadPara: Oxfam America and others, on the promise of the new development goals.

headline: The Panthers’ Revolutionary Feminism
leadPara: As “The Black Panthers: Vanguard of the Revolution” describes, imagery of the Panthers featured its male leaders, but by the end of the 1960s the party was composed mainly of women.
abstract: Stanley Nelson documentary The Black Panthers: Vanguard of the Revolution shines spotlight on gender contradictions within the party; as women increasingly reached all levels of the organization, male leaders had mixed responses to their push for equality.

headline: Democrats Find That Anti-Establishment Isn’t Just a G.O.P. Theme
leadPara: An anti-establishment mood in the Democratic Party is not only fueling the presidential campaign of Bernie Sanders, but also pushing liberals to mount more aggressive challenges to party-backed congressional candidates.
abstract: Anti-establishment sentiments are harming presidential campaign of Hillary Rodham Clinton, and fueling rise of Sen Bernie Sanders; left's growing discontent with Democratic Party's progress on income equality and other progressive causes are also driving outsider candidates in Senate and House elections; some see analogy with Tea Party's effect on Republican Party.

headline: How a New York Accent Can Help You Get Ahead
leadPara: Bernie Sanders has one. So does Donald Trump. Do voters just want to tawk?
abstract: Op-Ed article by linguist Michael Newman argues that conversational style of presidential candidates Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump, both native New Yorkers, helps explain their popularity with voters; contrasts their speech's 'indexicality,' which projects frankness and assertiveness, with other candidates' more attenuated tones.

headline: American Apparel Files for Bankruptcy
leadPara: No layoffs were announced in the filing, which still requires approval by the bankruptcy court and is part of a deal that would let the clothing retailer keep most of its 130 U.S. stores open.
abstract: American Apparel files for bankruptcy citing debt, plummeting sales and legal issues; deal will allow company to keep manufacturing operations and stores open, and no layoffs are announced.

headline: A Dark Vision From French Intellectuals
leadPara: A few philosopher-pundits have taken center stage in France’s political debate, arguing that the country is in danger of losing its soul.

headline: California Leads a Quiet Revolution
leadPara: The state is cruising toward its 2020 goal for increasing renewable energy and is setting far more ambitious targets for the future.

headline: Bernie Sanders, a Hunting-State Senator, Treads Lightly With Guns
leadPara: Mr. Sanders’s more moderate views are facing scrutiny in a Democratic field that is pushing hard for strict controls after a mass shooting in Oregon.
abstract: Democratic presidential hopeful Sen Bernie Sanders of Vermont, a state where hunting is prevalent, is facing renewed scrutiny over his moderate positions on gun control and Second Amendment in aftermath of mass shooting in Oregon.

headline: Bernie Sanders to Appear on ‘Ellen DeGeneres Show’ Next Week
abstract: Bernie Sanders will appear on “The Ellen DeGeneres Show” next Thursday, and a spokesman says the senator knows that “a little dancing is part of the drill.”

headline: The Immigration Dividend
leadPara: Does an open-door policy enhance a nation’s security and prosperity? The U.S has 59 million reasons the answer is yes.
abstract: Op-Ed article by Ted Widmer underscores degree to which Immigration and Nationality Act of 1965 helped United States become better nation; suggests success of act makes case for further opening nation's doors to immigrants seeking to become American citizens.

headline: How Did the Democrats Become Favorites of the Rich?
leadPara: The party now depends as much on affluent voters as on low-income voters.

headline: What Defunding Planned Parenthood Would Really Mean
abstract: It would be cruel, foolish and possibly unconstitutional.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

headline: Bernie Sanders Gets First Congressional Endorsement, From Raúl Grijalva
abstract: The endorsement from Representative Raúl Grijalva of Arizona is Senator Bernie Sanders’s first nod of support from a member of Congress, and he gets it just ahead of next week’s first Democratic debate.

headline: New-York Historical Society to Open Women’s History Center
leadPara: The Center for the Study of Women’s History, devoted to exhibitions and scholarship, is to open in early 2017.
abstract: New-York Historical Society, inspired by revelation that many Tiffany lamps in its collection were actually created by Clara Driscoll and female staff of Tiffany Studios' glass cutting department, plans to redesign fourth floor of its building into gallery for lamps and Center for the Study of Women’s History; intends to host workshops, classes and conferences and offer fellowships in largely overlooked study of women's history.

headline: Jessica Mendoza Defies Boundaries and Critics
leadPara: Mendoza, an all-American and an Olympic gold medalist as a softball player, has performed so well for ESPN in place of the suspended Curt Schilling that she appears to have earned an enhanced role in its future baseball coverage.

headline: Mark Penn’s Stagwell Group Will Acquire SKDKnickerbocker
leadPara: The private equity firm founded with a check from Steve Ballmer is buying the public relations firm known for its campaign work with Democratic clients.
abstract: Stagwell Group, private equity firm staked by former Microsoft chief Steven A Ballmer, will acquire public relations group SKDKnickerbocker for undisclosed amount; acquisition is first step in what Stagwell chief executive Mark Penn says is attempt to create cohesive group of advertising, research, public relations and marketing companies.

headline: Comedy Listings for Oct. 9-15
leadPara: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Found on Facebook: Empathy
leadPara: According to several recent studies, social media, long a haven for selfies and minutiae, could actually increase our capacity to feel for others.
abstract: Teddy Wayne Future Tense column observes while conventional wisdom argues that social media appears to have decreased people's capacity for empathy, new research shows it does allow people to experience more closeness with others.

headline: Martin O’Malley Counting on Debate to Urge Voters to Think Beyond 2 Democrats
leadPara: The Democratic debate will give Mr. O’Malley, a former governor of Maryland and mayor of Baltimore, the opportunity to share the spotlight with Hillary Rodham Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders.
abstract: First Democratic presidential debate will provide former Maryland Gov Martin O'Malley with best chance yet to draw attention from frontrunners Hillary Rodham Clinton and Bernie Sanders; O'Malley has had very low poll numbers despite impressive political record.

headline: Is Money Corrupting Research?
leadPara: Elizabeth Warren was right to expose the academic-financial complex.
abstract: Op-Ed article by Luigi Zingales examines implications of resignation of economist Robert Litan from Brookings Institution after Sen Elizabeth Warren raised question of whether Litan's testimony before Senate about Labor Dept rule was compromised by payment from mutual fund company Capital Group; suggests best way to ensure expert testimony offered in congressional hearings is not affected by conflicts of interest is to make process fully transparent.

headline: From Fracking to Finance, a Torrent of Campaign Cash
leadPara: The super-affluent throw tens of millions of dollars into candidate and “super PAC” coffers, seeking to influence the 2016 presidential race.

headline: Flat Wages Add to Allure of the ‘Anti-Politician’ in Reliably Red States
leadPara: The economy in general and stagnant wages in particular have some Republican voters looking for a leader who is not entrenched in American politics.
abstract: So-called anti-politicians like Donald Trump are enjoying sustained surge in Republican polls in red state of South Carolina, with many voters angry over dysfunction in Washington, weak economy and stagnant wages for middle class, among other issues; many residents say they will vote for outsider candidate in 2016 presidential election.

headline: Elizabeth Copeland, Harry Stein
leadPara: The couple met while playing on opposing teams in kickball.

headline: Jersey City Proposes Legislation to Legalize Airbnb
leadPara: Mayor Steven M. Fulop anticipates a 6 percent hospitality tax would generate between $600,000 and $1 million annually on the more than 300 Airbnb listings in the city.
abstract: Jersey City Mayor Steven M Fulop will introduce legislation legalizing all short-term sleepover web services, like Airbnb and HomeAway; legislation will require Airbnb users to pay city 6 percent hospitality tax levied on hotel guests; tax is expected to bring $600,000 to $1 million annually.

headline: The Crazies and the Con Man
leadPara: The media haven’t recognized what has happened to the Republican Party, and that’s where Paul Ryan sees his opportunity to shine.
abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column argues that Rep Paul Ryan's fiscal acumen is a myth; asserts movement to draft him as next House Speaker is based solely on his perceived credibility to those outside his party; accuses media of refusing to admit this, which would force them to recognize Republicans are no longer serious abut policy.

headline: ‘SuperBetter’ and ‘The State of Play’
leadPara: A program uses the principles of play for self-improvement, and essays trace the evolution of video-game intellectual culture.
abstract: Simon Parkin reviews books Superbetter: A Revolutionary Approach to Getting Stronger, Happier, Braver, and More Resilient -- Powered by the Science of Games by Jane McGonigal and The State of Play: Creators and Critics on Video Game Culture, edited by Daniel Goldberg and Linus Larsson.

headline: Joshua Wong Seeks Lower Age Limit for Hong Kong Candidates
abstract: Mr. Wong, who turns 19 on Tuesday, is seeking to lower the minimum age for candidates to the Legislative Council to 18, from 21.

headline: The ‘Submission’ of Michel Houellebecq: Interview Excerpts
leadPara: Excerpts from an interview with Mr. Houellebecq about his new novel and why Europe is an undemocratic “nightmare.”

headline: The Dangers of Indifference
leadPara: The consequences of looking the other way on Europe's refugee crisis are deadly.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Democratic Debate Magic
leadPara: With a poised, polished performance, she eclipsed Bernie Sanders in their first face-off of the race.
abstract: Frank Bruni Op-Ed column applauds Hillary Rodham Clinton's performance in first Democratic presidential debate; holds Clinton remained confident, appearing as buoyant upstart, despite decades in political trenches, while rival Bernie Sanders seemed repetitive and irascible; expresses surprise at Clinton's finesse and at directions race has taken.

headline: Democratic Debate Turns Hillary Clinton’s Way After Months of Difficulties
leadPara: Mrs. Clinton was blunt in saying that she had a liberal political philosophy but was also a pragmatic leader who would work with both Democrats and Republicans.
abstract: News Analysis; Hillary Rodham Clinton delivers strong performance at first Democratic presidential debate after months of difficulties; emotes liberal rallying cry as debate plays to her strengths and to her rivals' limitations, including those of Sen Bernie Sanders.

headline: Full Transcript: Democratic Presidential Debate
leadPara: The full dialogue from the debate hosted by CNN and Facebook from the Wynn Resort in Las Vegas.

headline: In First Debate, Democrats Keep the Drama to a Minimum
leadPara: If the Republican candidates went to their debates to deliver smackdowns, the Democrats showed up for a singalong in Las Vegas, largely avoiding attacking one another.

headline: Europe’s Threat From Within
leadPara: The refugee crisis might be an external challenge, but what really worries Brussels is the growing strength of the Continent’s regional separatists.

headline: In Debate, Hillary Clinton Sent a Message to Doubters
leadPara: Mrs. Clinton sent an unmistakable message to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and their fellow Democrats that she is up for a fight.
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton's confident performance in first Democratic presidential debate has allayed skeptics' doubts about her candidacy and dampened prospects for run by Vice Pres Joe Biden; prior calls for Biden to enter race have been based to large extent on assumption that Clinton would falter, opening space to be filled by vice president.

headline: Hillary Clinton Wins Iowa Fans With Debate Performance
leadPara: Iowa has been friendly territory for Bernie Sanders, but even those who are fond of him said they were taking a new look at Mrs. Clinton.
abstract: Many Iowans come away from first Democratic presidential debate impressed with Hillary Rodham Clinton's performance; number of progressives say Clinton's self-assurance and command of issues brought her new respect and support and felt her responses showed a stronger potential for working with Republicans in Congress than Sanders.

headline: Reviewing the Democratic Debate
leadPara: Readers praise the issues-oriented discussion but criticize The Times’s coverage and disagree on who performed best.

headline: A Feminism Where ‘Lean In’ Means Leaning On Others
abstract: Mainstream feminism focused on climbing the corporate ladder cannot achieve justice for women, or anyone else.

headline: Tammy Baldwin Has One Thing in Common With Trump
leadPara: The junior senator, 53, from Wisconsin on the many things the rest of the country can learn from the Midwest, and why the casserole is not one of them.
abstract: Ana Marie Cox Talk interview with Tammy Baldwin, first openly gay senaotor who is campaigning in her native Wisconsin and elsewhere in Midwest for Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Why Tipping Is Wrong
leadPara: For decades, tips have been the excuse not to pay restaurant workers even a minimum wage.
abstract: Op-Ed article by food labor advocate Saru Jayaraman applauds restaurateur Danny Meyer's decision to eliminate tipping from his restaurants and urges adoption of reforms eliminating tipped wages across New York State; highlights racist and classist history of tipping practice; asserts low restaurant wages continue to disproportionately affect women and minorities.

headline: Read This | Recommendations From the Teenagers on Our Student Council
abstract: We asked the 22 teenagers named to our new Student Council what one recent Times piece they’d recommend to others their age and why. The result: a reading list of such interesting variety we can’t imagine there isn’t something here for everyone.

headline: Canadian Campaign Blurs Party Lines to Thwart Conservatives
leadPara: Opponents of Prime Minister Stephen Harper want change after three elections in which he has won power with only 39.6 percent of the popular vote.
abstract: Canvassers in Canada's national election beseech voters to set party loyalty aside and vote for whichever opposition candidate has best chance of beating conservative Canadian Prime Min Stephen Harper, who has won three previous elections with no more than 39.6 percent of vote.

headline: Tunisia’s Islamic Democrats
leadPara: An Ennahdha official writes that his party “played a significant role” in developing a progressive constitution for Tunisia.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s First Town Hall Meeting
leadPara: The event, which focused on rent regulation and tenant protection, was something he should have done long ago.
abstract: Editorial applauds New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio for holding unscripted, town-hall-style meeting in Washington Heights, calling event long overdue; asserts mayor must remain engaged with communities in city, even while pushing his progressive agenda nationwide; urges de Blasio to hold many more such meetings.

headline: Schools for Wisdom
leadPara: A new documentary promotes an educational approach suited for modern times and the modern workplace. But it shortchanges intellectual virtues.
abstract: David Brooks Op-Ed column examines Greg Whiteley documentary film Most Likely to Succeed, which argues America's content-based school system is outdated, while collaborative, project-based education is more appropriate to modern workplace; contends film's argument is partially correct; holds while soft skills like motivation and perseverance are important, true wisdom requires factual acquisition and cultural literacy.

headline: Guess Who Else Is a Socialist?
leadPara: We don’t like ‘them.’ But we do like many of their ideas. At its best the system can run an army, and health care, and provide quality education.

headline: With Anti-Muslim Campaign, Canada Has Its Trump Moment
leadPara: Used to the moral high ground, Canadians are watching their own politics getting dragged into divisive immigrant-bashing.
abstract: Op-Ed article by journalist Martin Patriquin assails Canada's ruling Conservative Party for stoking fears over Muslim veiling for political gain; notes Prime Min Stephen Harper has vowed to fight Supreme Court ruling allowing veils during citizenship ceremonies; suggests Conservative strategy may ultimately backfire.

headline: Indian Writers Return Awards to Protest Government Silence on Violence
leadPara: The revolt now confronts Prime Minister Narendra Modi with a critical test of his vaunted ability to shape the public narrative of his administration.
abstract: Thirty-five leading Indian authors and poets have returned literary honors in protest of what they say is rise in Hindu nationalist-driven violence since election of Prime Min Narendra Modi; dissent presents Modi with test of his ability to shape public perception of his administration, seen by some as progressive and by others as dogmatic.

headline: Fearing Election Losses, Taiwan’s Governing Party Drops Its Presidential Candidate
leadPara: The Kuomintang, or Nationalist Party, chose Eric Chu on Saturday as its new nominee, replacing Hung Hsiu-chu, who has trailed badly in the polls.
abstract: Taiwanese governing party Kuomintang selects new presidential candidate, party chairman and New Taipei City mayor Eric Chu, reversing its nomination for Hung Hsiu-chu after polls showed her trailing opposition Democratic Progressive Party candidate Tsai Ing-wen.

headline: In Unpredictable Canadian Elections, Plurality Is More Important Than Popularity
leadPara: Each of the three big parties has led in one poll or another, but the country’s robust, dizzying political culture puts the race well beyond the reach of trustworthy handicapping.
abstract: Polling experts say it is hard to predict Canadian elections because winners are decided by plurality or who gets the most votes; race could lean towards Conservatives, well-funded incumbents who held power for nine years without ever winning more than 40 percent of vote.

headline: New York Today: The Tipping Point
leadPara: Restaurant rules, cool conditions, and neighborly news.

headline: Turkey’s Self-Inflicted Disaster
leadPara: The Ankara attack was the tragic and preventable result of misguided and dangerous policies.

headline: Bernie Sanders Can’t Escape Questions About 2007 Vote on Immigration Overhaul
abstract: Despite efforts to broaden his support, Senator Bernie Sanders may continue to face questions from Hispanics about his vote against a comprehensive immigration overhaul bill in 2007.

headline: Behind Thick-Rimmed Glasses, Cubs’ Joe Maddon Takes a Rose-Colored Approach
leadPara: Maddon, the Chicago manager, has kept his players cheerful by digging into his bag of psychological tools as heartily as he did during his years with the Rays.
abstract: Preview of third playoff game between New York Mets and Chicago Cubs, whose manager Joe Maddon is intent on keeping his team upbeat and cheerful despite trailing Mets 2-0 in series.

headline: Why Ben Carson’s Nazi Analogies Matter
leadPara: The candidate’s rhetorical recklessness damages our political culture and the conservative cause.
abstract: Peter Wehner Op-Ed article expresses concern over several instances in which Ben Carson has likened contemporary America to Nazi Germany; suggests analogies are of a piece with Carson's general rhetorical recklessness; warns that such rhetoric discredits Carson, and expresses hope that Republican voters will not nominate Carson for presidency.

headline: The Strange Case of Anna Stubblefield
leadPara: She told the family of a severely disabled man that she could help him to communicate with the outside world. The relationship that followed would lead to a criminal trial.
abstract: Case of Anna Stubblefield, married psychology professor who fell in love with mentally disabled man with cerebral palsy known by name DJ, has perplexed many and presented moral quandary to jury and world; Stubblefield claims facilitated communication, much-debated technique she used with DJ, revealed normal intelligence hidden to most; Stubblefield faces 10 to 20 years in prison for sexual assault of man with mentality of child.

headline: For Canada, Most Noticeable Change Under Justin Trudeau Could Be Tone
leadPara: Mr. Trudeau has spoken not just of policy changes but also of putting an end to Stephen Harper’s often belligerent style of politics and diplomacy.
abstract: Election of Justin Trudeau as prime minister of Canada is likely to lead to significant shift in tone, as Trudeau promised to jettison his predecessor Stephen Harper's often brusque style of politics and diplomacy.

headline: The Most Diverse S.E.C. Ever May Be Taking Shape
leadPara: If confirmed, four of the five commissioners will be women for the first time, and one would be only the third African-American commissioner in the history of the agency.
abstract: President Obama nominates Lisa M Fairfax as commissioner of Securities and Exchange Commission and Hester Maria Peirce to fill Republican vacancy on commission; if both nominations are confirmed, group that makes up SEC commissioners will be most diverse ever.

leadPara: The liberal Capitol Hill neighborhood in Washington, D.C. provides a test case in the national debate over high incarceration rates.

headline: A One-Term U.S. President
abstract: Two millennials debate whether a one-term presidency would be good for the nation's future.

headline: Chance the Rapper to Perform at Terminal 5
leadPara: The hip-hop singer will take the stage with a band, the Social Experiment.

headline: Joe Biden’s Moving On, and So Should We

headline: Jacob Riis Photographs Still Revealing New York’s Other Half
leadPara: A new retrospective spotlights the indelible 19th-century photographs of New York slums that set off a reform movement.
abstract: Sam Roberts reviews Museum of the City of New York exhibit Jacob A Riis: Revealing New York's Other Half, featuring Riis photographs as well as documents and artifacts.

headline: New Scrutiny on Vote Buying as Argentine Elections Near
leadPara: The practice, which is not illegal, was called a scourge last month in local voting, but raises questions about the frailty of the nation’s democracy.
abstract: Widespread practice of vote-buying in Argentina has come under increased scrutiny in advance of upcoming parliamentary and presidential elections and has raised concerns about strength of country's democracy; election observers have outlined extent of practice, which is not actually illegal.

headline: The Disproportionate Risks of Driving While Black
leadPara: An examination of traffic stops and arrests in Greensboro, N.C., uncovered wide racial differences in measure after measure of police conduct.
abstract: New York Times analysis of tens of thousands of traffic stops and years of arrest data reveals wide racial disparities in policing in racially mixed city of Greensboro, NC, and elsewhere in state; data shows officers are far more likely to make traffic stops, search cars, make arrests and resort to force when dealing with black motorists than with whites; bias can have deep and lasting effects on both black individuals and communities.

headline: Voice Is Sought at the Vatican on Remarriage
leadPara: A question of how far bishops will go in backing Pope Francis’ call for a church more open to the complicated, less-than-perfect lives of modern Catholics.
abstract: Group of divorced and remarried Catholics appeal to bishops during conclusion of three-week Vatican assembly on family issues to be more inclusive of complicated lives of modern practitioners of the faith, including gay Catholics; bishops are preparing to present their recommendations shortly.

headline: The Central Bank Skeptic Who Helped Give Birth to the Fed
leadPara: A trip to Europe persuaded the conservative senator Nelson W. Aldrich, who had been opposed to a central bank, to lay the groundwork for what became the Fed.
abstract: Roger Lowenstein Hindsight column profiles conservative senator Nelson W Aldrich, who played pivotal role in founding of Federal Reserve in early 20th century; after fact-finding tour of central banking systems of Europe, he helped devise plan for central bank that worked on hub-and-spoke model; Federal Reserve Act borrowed his idea in creating Fed.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Attack in Iowa, but Targets Diverge
leadPara: Mrs. Clinton used a speech in Des Moines to link herself closely to President Obama, but Mr. Sanders turned his sights directly on his rival.
abstract: Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton, during speech at Iowa fundraising dinner, attacks Republican opponents but spares her Democratic rivals; by contrast, candidates Sen Bernie Sanders and former Gov Martin O'Malley, both speaking at same event, sharply criticize Clinton's record and proposals without citing her by name.

headline: Democratic Dinner Drives Home Hillary Clinton’s Focus on Iowa
leadPara: Hillary Rodham Clinton has gone to great lengths to prevent Senator Bernie Sanders from undermining her campaign the way another senator, Barack Obama, did in the state in 2008.
abstract: Political Memo; Hillary Rodham Clinton, whose slim lead in Iowa polls make her vulnerable to Sen Bernie Sanders, uses Democratic party dinner in Des Moines to consolidate gains and conserve momentum; 2008 event fed rise of Barack Obama and eclipse of her previous campaign, slip aides are working hard not to repeat.

headline: The New Face of Fandango, Born in a Movie Theater

abstract: Advertising column; Fandango will introduce advertising character Miles Mouvay, played by comedian Kenan Thompson, in launch of multi-media, multimillion-dollar ad campaign; effort is intended to display growth of Fandango, owned by Comcast, past just movie ticket seller into full-fledged entertainment hub.

leadPara: What is to be done with Islamists? A repeat of Tunisia's success is very unlikely.

abstract: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio is expected to endorse Hillary Rodham Clinton for Democratic presidential nomination; many close to de Blasio questioned his reluctance to make endorsement over policy differences.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEITELMAN, LEO H.
leadPara: SEITELMAN--Leo H.,passed away peacefully after a short illness at the age of 97.5. Mr. Seitelman was a graduate of City College with honors in accounting. He was a Certified Public Accountant in his own practice for many years. He was also a World War II Veteran (Army-Chief Warrant Officer in Finance). One of his proudest accomplishments was being president of Temple Beth Emeth v'Ohr Progressive Shaari Zedek of Flatbush, Brooklyn. He leaves behind sons Mark (Minna) and Edward, and grandchildren and great-grandchildren. The Funeral is on Friday, October 30th, at 11:30am at The Weinstein Chapels, 1153 Coney Island Ave., at Ave. H, Brooklyn, with burial to follow. 1/3

headline: European Parliament Urges Protection for Edward Snowden
leadPara: A nonbinding resolution expressed strong support for Mr. Snowden, calling on European Union members to regard him as a whistle-blower and grant him protection.
abstract: European Parliament issues strongest support yet for Edward J Snowden, recognizing him as 'whistle-blower and international human rights defender'; designation is non-binding and while former National Security Agency contractor is currently in Russia, no countries in Europe have offered Snowden permanent asylum to date.

headline: Scandal-Plagued San Francisco Sheriff Limps to Election Day
leadPara: Sheriff Ross Mirkarimi is running for re-election on Tuesday against an opponent who has gained support from Mr. Mirkarimi’s own deputies and staff members.
abstract: Political observers say incumbent San Francisco Sheriff Ross Mirkarimi is unlikely to be re-elected, despite fact that his progressive politics are more of match to liberal city than those of his opponent Vicki Hennessy; Mirkarimi's tenure has been characterized by series of scandals, which has led even many of his own deputies and staff members to support Hennessy.

headline: Review: In ‘Our Brand Is Crisis,’ the War Room Goes to Bolivia

headline: Ghostly Transcends Its Record Label Roots to Sell an Ethos
leadPara: The label, which began in 1999, has expanded into an online boutique offering items like watches, eyeglasses and art to taste-conscious cultural consumers.

abstract: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio officially endorses presidential candidacy of Hillary Rodham Clinton during appearance on MSNBC television program Morning Joe; announcement comes months after de Blasio initially denied Clinton his endorsement and is given comparatively little notice by Clinton campaign, reflecting reduced interest in his endorsement.

leadPara: Some of America’s biggest private foundations are focusing on major issues like climate change and income inequality with an eye toward rapid results.

headline: The Mystery of the Vanishing Pay Raise
leadPara: Despite economic recovery, the share of corporate income going to workers has sunk to its lowest level since 1951.
abstract: News Analysis; Americans' wages have remained stubbornly flat since 2009, despite unemployment rate falling substantially since end of recession; reasons for stagnant wages are varied, although some economists see hope for higher wages in efforts to increase minimum wage as well as base wages at chain restaurants and large retailers.

leadPara: Readers respond to articles on a variety of topics recently published in the section.

headline: San Francisco Ballots Turn Up Anger Over the Technical Divide
leadPara: On Tuesday, voters will weigh in on propositions linked to the technology industry and rising housing costs, including one to restrict Airbnb’s home-sharing.
abstract: San Franciscans will vote on 11 propositions, and candidates for various offices, in election that is widely seen as referendum on city's booming technology industry and soaring real estate prices; Prop F would restrict Airbnb and Prop I would stop development in Mission District.

headline: The Creator of WorldStarHipHop Plots His Second Act

abstract: Lee O'Denat, founder of WorldStarHipHop.com, spends day in Los Angeles discussing plans for controversial hip-hop website's future amid several business meetings.

headline: Steve Deace and the Power of Conservative Media
leadPara: When the radio host speaks for angry Republicans in Iowa — and beyond — the 2016 candidates have no choice but to listen.
abstract: Iowa radio talk show host Steve Deace has become voice for generation of angry conservative Republicans who have become increasingly uncompromising in their views toward government; Deace has caught attention of presidential candidates who must take his followers' views into account if they wish to win over divided party.

headline: Catholicism For the Time Being
abstract: When muddling through is the better part of valor.

headline: China, Taiwan and a Meeting After 66 Years
leadPara: President Ma Ying-jeou of Taiwan is to confer with President Xi Jinping of China in Singapore on Saturday, according to statements from both.
abstract: Chinese Pres Xi Jinping and Taiwanese Pres Ma Ying-jeou are set to meet in Singapore, first such meeting since before 1949 Chinese revolution; conciliatory gesture on Xi's part reflects his proclivity for political risk-taking, but experts say countries, which enjoy good economic relationship, are unlikely to reach significant political breakthrough.

headline: 중국-대만, 분단 후 66년 만에 첫 정상회담

headline: When Leaders of Taiwan and China Meet, Even Tiny Gestures Will Be Parsed
leadPara: For the historic meeting between Ma Ying-jeou and Xi Jinping, nothing will be left to chance. Especially how they address each other.
abstract: Officials from China and Taiwan hammer out protocol for historic November meeting in Singapore of their leaders, Xi Jinping and Ma Ying-jeou; say agreement on etiquette, including how they will address each other, is necessary because of unresolved animosity between two countries that began when Taiwan sought independence; leaders from both countries face pressure not to legitimize each other’s political standing or ideologies through speech or gesture.

headline: Public Companies Trying to Mimic Private Firms

abstract: Companies like Dell and Uber that have gone private or forgone public offerings are raising robust capital nonetheless, undermining longstanding notion that public markets provide most efficient financing; some academics believe aversion may also be informed by desire to avoid short-term pressures of public companies.

leadPara: During his 2010 race for the Senate, Mr. Paul appealed to Kentuckians who believed in shutting down the government to advance their goals.

headline: Airbnb and Uber Mobilize Vast User Base to Sway Policy
leadPara: Leading companies in the sharing economy, like Airbnb and Uber, are turning their millions of users into an enormous political operation to fight back against unfavorable policies.
abstract: Sharing companies Airbnb and Uber, looking to fight cities trying to regulate them, are converting their users into huge political operation to sway policy and counter threats; Airbnb defeats San Francisco effort to regulate it and warns other cities considering such actions.

leadPara: The meeting in Singapore between Xi Jinping and Ma Ying-jeou comes amid increasing wariness among Taiwan voters of Beijing’s embrace.
abstract: Pres Xi Jinping of China and Taiwanese Pres Ma Ying-jeou make history by meeting for first time; many see diplomatic session in Singapore as breakthrough gesture by both nations toward peace after decades of bitter rivalry.

headline: Afghan Mullah Leading Stoning Inquiry Condones Practice
leadPara: A mullah’s theological support for the sort of stoning he is being sent to investigate is emblematic of the national conundrum over the role of Shariah law.
abstract: Mullah Maulavi Baleegh, one of religious leaders appointed Pres Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan to investigate fatal stoning of 19-year-old woman by Taliban on charges of adultery, says in sermon he supports Shariah law under which her punishment was meted out.

abstract: Frank Bruni Op-Ed column examines Houston referendum that overwhelmingly rejected anti-discrimination law; contends defeat was result of hatemongering that fixated public on groundless fear bill would allow transgender men to sneak into women's public bathrooms for ulterior purposes; examines slander spread by opposition through lens of his own pain as gay man who grew up bombarded by fear-based caricatures and stereotypes of himself as sexual deviant and predator.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASON, NONDITA
leadPara:
MASON--Nondita.

Nondita Mason, a retired professor of postcolonial literature and theory at Hunter College, died on September 25 at her Manhattan apartment, one day after returning from a 23-day trip to Italy, Greece, and Turkey with her husband, Bryant Mason. They climbed the Acropolis to see the Parthenon in Athens; cruised the Aegean to Santorini, Rhodes, Patmos, Mykonos, and Limnos; heard classical music at an illuminated Greek amphitheater at Ephesus in Turkey; toured Istanbul, and visited the Coliseum and the Vatican among other historic sites. Ms. Mason was most happy to have her Brooklyn nephew, Indro Chaudhury Sartorio, join her in Rome. The cause was long-term complications of bronchiectasis, a disease for which there is no cure. "After 15 years of suffering with this disease, she simply ran out of energy, but we had a wonderful last trip together," her husband wrote. She was 73. They lived in Manhattan and on Atlantic Avenue in Amagansett. Ms. Mason regularly taught a course on V.S. Naipaul, the focus of her doctoral dissertation at New York University. She retired in 2008. In her daily life, her husband described her as "a private person and a consummate communicator, keenly aware of justice and injustice, and always with a captivating smile for the people she met. She was radiant with energy when preparing for and engaging with students in her classrooms." She always took note when students were "full of questions and surprises," but was firm when they did not live up to expectations, her husband said. She strived to inspire them to weave their perspectives with accurate information and "logically progressive thoughts." In announcing her death to faculty, the Hunter English department called her a "superb teacher, a valued mentor to junior colleagues, and an inspiring colleague," Mr. Mason said. She brought compassion, intelligence, and insight to everything she did at the college, her colleagues stated.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODE, FREDERICK
leadPara:
GOODE--Frederick Wilson.

Died at home in Berkeley, CA, on November 2, 2015. He was born in New York on January 3, 1926. He graduated in 1947 from Princeton with honors and degrees in Art History and Comparative Religion. He served as a Navy Lieutenant in both the Second World War and the Korean War. Frederick's career as a high school teacher began by chance when he was asked to fill in as a substitute religion teacher at St. George's School in Newport, RI. He was a gifted and versatile teacher and actor who taught the humanities at college preparatory schools on both coasts. He was well known for his booming voice, humor, mimicry and classroom theatrics, sometimes throwing books or jumping on top of a desk to convey his passion for the subjects he loved. Frederick will be remembered as the director and co-founder of The School of Arts and Sciences, an experimental high school in San Anselmo, CA. Here Frederick and his colleague David Donnelley were able to put into practice their innovative and progressive ideas on education. The school emphasized collaboration rather than competition, and encouraged students to be conscious of social values and the need to protect the environment. Frederick met his wife, Marilyn Van Hoosear, while she was attending graduate school at New York University. The two were married in 1955 and had a litter of five children: Jennifer, Eric and Christopher who live in New York; and Gregory and Melissa who live in California. Frederick is survived by seven grandchildren. After retiring in 1989, Frederick lived in Sonoma with Marilyn and kept a small studio in Berkeley. Over the years his paintings were shown in various galleries in Seattle and the San Francisco Bay Area. In 2002, Frederick met his partner Panya Pringchamras, with whom he lived from 2008 until his death. Frederick loved books, gardens, nature and life. He was a brilliant and complex man who will be missed by his family, his friends, and the many students he inspired.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODE, FREDERICK WILSON
leadPara: GOODE--Frederick Wilson. Died at home in Berkeley, CA, on November 2, 2015. He was born in New York on January 3, 1926. He graduated in 1947 from Princeton with honors and degrees in Art History and Comparative Religion. He served as a Navy Lieutenant in both the Second World War and the Korean War. Frederick's career as a high school teacher began by chance when he was asked to fill in as a substitute religion teacher at St. George's School in Newport, RI. He was a gifted and versatile teacher and actor who taught the humanities at college preparatory schools on both coasts. He was well known for his booming voice, humor, mimicry and classroom theatrics, sometimes throwing books or jumping on top of a desk to convey his passion for the subjects he loved. Frederick will be remembered as the director and co-founder of The School of Arts and Sciences, an experimental high school in San Anselmo, CA. Here Frederick and his colleague David Donnelley were able to put into practice their innovative and progressive ideas on education. The school emphasized collaboration rather than competition, and encouraged students to be conscious of social values and the need to protect the environment. Frederick met his wife, Marilyn Van Hoosear, while she was attending graduate school at New York University. The two were married in 1955 and had a litter of five children: Jennifer, Eric and Christopher who live in New York; and Gregory and Melissa who live in California. Frederick is survived by seven grandchildren. After retiring in 1989, Frederick lived in Sonoma with Marilyn and kept a small studio in Berkeley. Over the years his paintings were shown in various galleries in Seattle and the San Francisco Bay Area. In 2002, Frederick met his partner Panya Pringchamras, with whom he lived from 2008 until his death. Frederick loved books, gardens, nature and life. He was a brilliant and complex man who will be missed by his family, his friends, and the many students he inspired. 1/3
